intro.title: TRANSLATOR’S INTRODUCTION
intro.p: Here is one version of the story.1 Reb Tsadok haCohen of Lublin was traveling to various rabbis in Poland to sign a heter mea rabbanim, the consent of a hundred rabbis in order to divorce his wife. At that time Reb Tsadok, famous as a genius, was one of the most illustrious members of the mitnagdim, the opponents of hasidism who favored cerebral study over ecstatic devotion as the true form of Divine service. Eventually he reached the house of the “Mei HaShiloach,” Reb Mordechai Yosef in the town of Isbitza.2 “The Rebbe’s class would begin at midnight by wrestling with revealed matters in a passage of the Talmud. By the morning light the discourse reached the secret of the furnace that powers the universe. In their discussion they arrived at the fundamental point: How does one arrive at the knowledge of the will of God through the actions of man, and at the revelation of God’s presence through the study of the Torah and the fulfillment of its commandments?”

Reb Tsadok stayed to discuss the lesson with the Rebbe of Isbitza after the class. “The Mei HaShiloach suddenly broke off the discussion of the lesson, turned to Reb Tsadok and said: ‘Here we are, involved in the study of this passage of Talmud according to our own minds and wills, as if the very law that we are discussing is our own wisdom. At the same time we are saying from our own understanding that the Torah is the blessed God’s, and hidden within it is His very will, may He be blessed, in a way that through the process of Torah study we may merit to know the will of the blessed God at every moment, at every second. Together with this we may then feel the presence of the Shechina, which rests everywhere. Our sole objective is to ask: What in our study this evening has shown us the will of the Holy One, blessed be He, and what of it can proclaim the glory of heaven to the world? What of it can we use to fulfill our obligation to sanctify and love the Name of God in the world?’ In hearing the words from the mouth of the Mei HaShiloach, dread descended on Reb Tsadok’s heart, and he began to tremble in his entire being. He asked the Rebbe:
‘How can we understand the will of the Creator?’

‘By means of the study of Torah!’ answered the Mei HaShiloach. He continued, ‘A man who studies Torah must feel as if his feet are standing at the foot of Mount Sinai and he is hearing the Torah from the very mouth of the All Powerful. Then he knows that it is His blessed will.’
Reb Tsadok stood for a while, immersed in his thoughts. Days later, he would say of this conversation, ‘I felt as if he had placed burning coals on my heart.’”
As a result of this meeting, Reb Tsadok then became one of the principal students and hasidim of the Rebbe of Isbitza and his way, so remaining for the rest of his life.

“Many years later, it is told that in Reb Tsadok’s old age, the famous genius Rabbi Yosef Rojin, the Illui of Rogatchoff, visited the house of Reb Tsadok in order to engage the Cohen in pilpul, heated discourse in the law. Reb Tsadok said, ‘Your honor would like to know if I am a scholar. How will God be glorified in any way from this? This is not the reason why the sages of the great assembly instituted the blessing, ‘Blessed is God who grants man wisdom.’ In my youth, I too was involved in such pilpul over the law, but I arrived at the understanding that the only way to achieve knowledge of the Torah is through the gates of hasidism which the holy Baal Shem Tov had opened for us.”3

Who was Reb Mordechai Yosef of Isbitza, and how did he arrive at the revolutionary conception of the Torah found in his teachings? He was born in the town of Tomashov in Poland in 1800 (5560) to a rabbinic family. The introduction to the Beit Yaakov, the teachings of his son, traces the family’s lineage, each generation a leader of his community, back to Reb Moshe Issralis, the Ramo, and thus further to Rabbi Shlomo Yitchaki, Rashi, the leading medieval Torah commentator. Rashi then connects his lineage back to David haMelech. But as always, the fame of his family is not important. We are concerned with who he was. He grew up together with Rabbi Menachem Mendel Morgenstern, later to become “the Kotsker Rebbe.” The two were childhood friends and together were students and hasidim of Reb Simcha Bunem of Pshiske. It was from the Rebbe of Pshiske, the famous disciple of Yaakov Yitschak Horowitz, the “Seer of Lublin,” that the two received from the well-springs of the teachings of Rabbi Israel, the Baal Shem Tov, the founder of the hasidic movement.

In the introduction of the second volume of the Mei HaShiloach, it is told that when the young Reb Mordechai Yosef first met his teacher, Reb Simcha Bunem, the teacher said to him, almost joking, “come, let us see who is taller.” He motioned that they should compare height by standing back to back. This was peculiar, because where Mordechai Yosef was quite small in physique, Reb Simcha Bunem was of a large, strapping form. The Pshisker then said to him, “Now I am taller than you. But you are still young, and in the days to come you shall grow.” It was the Rebbe of Pshiske who gave Mordechai Yosef the name “the Mei HaShiloach,” the “waters from the spring of Shiloach.” This is the underground spring that flows from under the Temple Mount in Jerusalem and through the ancient city of David, now called Silwan. This was the place where the kings of the House of David were anointed. The meaning is akin to “still waters run deep,” which is the sense Simcha Bunem received from the quiet intensity of his young student. The Pshisker said, “he is like the waters of the Shiloach which flow slowly and search out the deepest depths.”4 This is reminiscent of the verse in Kohollet, “It is deep, exceedingly deep, and who can fathom it?”

When the Pshisker left this world, Reb Menachem Mendel became his successor, moving the center of operations to the town of Kotsk. Here in Kotsk, Mordechai Yosef, already his friend and study partner, became his disciple. There is much to say of this period, but it will not be said here. After some time the Kotsker closed himself in his room adjacent to the house of study, and there remained for the next twenty years until his death. When he would occasionally appear in his doorway, it was as the revelation of a Holy Seraph of God. In short, Mordechai Yosef objected to the Kotsker’s self-imposed confinement, and left for the town of Isbitza, taking ninety percent of the Kotsker hasidim along with him. How many Jews remained in Kotsk? A minyan (ten). He then sent a message back to Menachem Mendel, saying, “I promise to pay you back with children and grandchildren until the coming of the Messiah.”5 Of this whole period, you will hear different versions depending on whether if comes from Kotsk family history or Isbitza family history. The version of Isbitza follows in the next section, the introduction from the Dor Yesharim. As a young student in Pshiske, it is told that he basically lived in the house of study, even sleeping there. He would return to visit his family for holidays.

As mentioned below in the Dor Yesharim, the Mei HaShiloach never wrote down his insights into the Torah. Even his students refrained from writing, but would rather commit his words to memory and later discuss the meaning of the Rebbe’s teaching. This was also the case with the Baal Shem Tov. A story is told of the Baal Shem Tov seeing one of his students writing down his words of Torah. He looked at the writings and said, “not a word of what I have said have you written.” The introduction to the second volume of the Mei HaShiloach describes how the book was written. “Indeed a number of years after he was taken from us, a number of the students of the Mei HaShiloach took it upon themselves to collect that which they remembered from the teachings and commit them to writing. Then future generations will also benefit from the light of his holy teachings. They pleaded with the son of the Mei HaShiloach to help them in this endeavor, and he entrusted the task to his own son, Reb Gershon Chanoch Hainech [the first Radziner Rebbe].” That the words of the Isbitser Rebbe were written from memory during the twenty years following his death accounts for their terse, distilled character. This is not a work of literary merit; it is purely concerned with content. One must bear in mind that the writer of Mei HaShiloach felt as if he was writing what he remembered from the time he stood at Mount Sinai. Furthermore, the lessons were delivered in Yiddish, the Hebrew of the Bible, and the Aramaic of the Talmud and Zohar. Thus all that was Yiddish was then translated into Hebrew. Reb Gershon Chanoch published the first edition, an unedited of parts of the first volume, in the year 5620 (1860), four years after the Isbitzer left the world. It is told that the first printing of the Mei HaShiloach was done on a Gentile press and without any approbations from famous Rabbis of the generation, quite unusual for books of hasidic discourse to this day. The second volume of the Mei HaShiloach was put in writing and printed by Reb Gershon Chanoch’s brother, Reb Mordechai Yosef Elazar.

Who studies this work? I once met with Reb Yaakov Lainer in Borough Park, Brooklyn. The son of the late Radziner Rebbe and a direct descendant of the Mei HaShiloach, he is the current publisher of Isbitza books in America. He told me that thirty years ago, his father, of blessed memory, would sell some twenty copies of the Mei HaShiloach each year. It was like a dinosaur. He told me that at that time it was only really studied by Jews who came from certain towns in Poland. Then in the late 1960s, Reb Shlomo Carlebach, may his memory be blessed, began his work of traveling seven continents to light Jewish hearts with the fire of hasidism. In his suitcase there was always a copy of the Mei HaShiloach. You could say that wherever he went, he took with him the light and profundity of the Isbitzer Rebbe, giving it to thirsty souls. I once heard him say, “you cannot understand the Chumash [five books of Moses] without the Mei HaShiloach.” In my conversation with Reb Lainer, he gave Shlomo Carlebach the credit for popularizing the Mei HaShiloach in our generation. In the six years I spent with Shlomo Carlebach, not a learning, not a Shabbos, went by without some light from the Isbitzer. Today it is found in every Hebrew bookstore, and is taught in every yeshiva of new young spirit seekers desiring inspiration from the hasidic masters. I used to spend much time in the shadow of Reb Yitschak Asher Twersky, of blessed memory, the Talner Rebbe of Boston. He is known as the pre-eminent scholar of Maimonides in this century. Sitting before him I always felt as if I was sitting before the Rambam. During one of his Drashot at the third meal of Shabbat, Parshat Beshalach in 1997, he quoted a teaching from the Mei HaShiloach on “Who is like You among the powers, Hashem.” He then said that he wanted to find time to teach a regular shiur (lesson) devoted to the Mei HaShiloach. But sadly, he was summoned to the world of Truth before he could realize this desire. I remember Rabbi Shlomo Riskin in Efrat, Israel, during his drash for Shabbat haGadol, the week before Passover, mentioning before 700 people a teaching from the Mei HaShiloach. Also in Efrat, I happened to walk into a class with Rabbi Chaim Brovender with a copy of the Mei HaShiloach under my arm. He noticed it, and said, “Be careful. If you learn enough of this you may burn up!” I mention these examples just to show how widespread the prevalence of the Mei HaShiloach has become for those receptive to the teachings of hasidism, whereas fifty years ago the name “Mei HaShiloach” would have gone unnoticed.

I beg forgiveness for doing something as brazen as trying to summarize the main principle of the Mei HaShiloach in a few sentences. First and foremost, everything is in the hands of Heaven. Everything that we receive in our lives, we are receiving directly from the blessed God. It is then the work of man in the world to develop a mind that is conscious of this reality. On top of a general unwavering dedication to the Torah and its laws, man must specifically work, through the study of the Torah and avodat Hashem, the service of God, to know what God wants of him specifically in his life. He must also then know that God’s will could change at any time, and must constantly look to God to illuminate into him what He wants of man at any particular moment. This also necessitates that he not assume that what God wants from him is the same as that which he wants from another. Even if he sees another transgressing the Torah, he may not assume that the other is rebelling against God’s will, for he has no way of knowing the private relationship between the other and God. Thus, through personal refinement in according to his illumination of the will of God, he develops the consciousness of the presence and intentions of God. In this way, redemption is really just a change of consciousness. Then his conduct based on this new redemptive consciousness serves to glorify and sanctify the Name of God in the world. Now we must look in the text to find examples of these ideas.

It is written in the Gemara (Berachot, 33b), “all is in the hands of Heaven, except the fear of Heaven.” Rashi comments, “everything comes to man from God, the length of his life, whether he is poor or rich, whether he is simple or wise. However, whether he is good or wicked does not come from Heaven, this is a choice delivered into the hands of man, where two ways are placed before him, and he shall choose the fear of God.” However, as the Mei HaShiloach writes in Parshat Vayeira, under “and Sarah denied it,” that this only applies to the limits of the understanding of man’s intellect. It is in fact necessary for man to believe that he chooses to serve God so he has the desire to perform, and then the service can be called the work of his hands. However, in reality, he is “taking from the treasure house of the King and giving back to the Kings,” in the saying of the Zohar (Shmini, 38a). So if all that man does is a result of the constant Providence of God, then even the sins of Israel are part of God’s greater plan. Needless to say that this is in the large view, and cannot be taken before the action as a license to act recklessly. The Gemara (Avoda Zara, 4b) claims that Israel sinned in making a golden calf only to encourage the proper repentance of later generations. Though they went ahead and made the idol, they made atonement and their repentance was accepted. As a result, the tribes were given the mitzvah of giving the half-shekel. If the result of their sin was the performance of their mitzvah, which is meritorious in God’s view, certainly God takes pleasure when every Jew returns to His law. And if even the sin is transformed into merit, how much more pleasing is it when Israel performs acts that from the outset are meritorious! Thus the Mei HaShiloach repeats several times the words of the Gemara (Gittin, 53a), “one cannot uphold the Torah unless he has failed in it.” After the fact, the failure only serves to deepen one’s appreciation of the essence of the commandment.

There is a level beyond man’s choice, and this is clearly expressed concerning the verse, “in the plain over against Suf” (Devarim, 1:1). There it is written, “Why were the sins of Israel discreetly mentioned through the names of the places where the sins occurred rather than by the mention of the time when they occurred? This is in order that man does not think that the sins were done according to their power of choice, and that they had the choice to remove themselves from the sin. The matter of place hints at this, for it was not possible for them to guard themselves from the sin and move to a different place.”

So too, we find the entire Davidic line, the very Messiah, as a result of the incest of Lot and his daughters. Also with Yehuda and Tamar, when he admits and says, “she is more righteous than I [mimeni],” the Gemara (Sotah, 10b) says, “here God was saying, ‘the whole incident came forth from Me [memeni].’ ” In Parshat Vayeishev, under “and Er,” the Mei HaShiloach writes, “For the Holy One, blessed be He, conducts all the structures of the kingdom of the House of David, according to structures such as these, even though at the time of the action it seemed like a sin … The secret of the House of David is greatly concealed, even from the prophets.”

So truly, all that we are receiving in this world is coming from the blessed God. On the verse, “Mercy and Truth will not abandon you” (Mishlei, 3:3), the Mei HaShiloach comments, “The verse is not formulated, ‘do not abandon Mercy and Truth,’ for truly the effluence of the blessed God descends constantly without interruption. Only man, from his side, needs to refine his heart and stand ready to receive, and not turn his back on this effluence, God forbid. But in His goodness the blessed God constantly effuses His effluence, and the man who longs for His Mereies shall not forsake them.”

Now it is up to man to develop a mind that constantly looks to the will of God to guide his actions. (Though this very effort must be a direct effect of God’s influence in the world.) This can be seen in all of the actions of Yaakov Avinu, but particularly when he went to bless the sons of Yosef. Yaakov said, “E-lohim who guided me all my life until this day.” The Rebbe of Isbitza explains, “for every action I do, no matter how small, I need the blessed God to illuminate His will into me. I even need it with this action [blessing Menashe and Efriam], where I saw how it is His will to change it [to bless the younger before the older], nevertheless I need to see even the second time how it is His blessed will. Truly in this matter Yaakov was the greatest of the Patriarchs, for to have the blessed God constantly lead one’s actions is a great level. This was the prayer of King David (Tehillim, 23:1), ‘God is my shepherd, I will lack nothing,’ meaning that the Providence of the blessed God will not be lacking from me, for He will always guide me, and I will be ever aware that the blessed God is guiding me.”

Two characters are presented in the Mei HaShiloach. One is typified by Yosef, or Efriam, and this type always looks to the judgment of the Torah in every matter. So too does this type feel a sense of holy rage when confronted with transgression of the Torah, as with Pinchas, who descended from Efriam. The other type is Yehuda, who constantly looks to the blessed God to tell him how to act. This appears in Parshat Vayeishev:

This is as it is said (Yesahya, 11:13), “Efriam shall not be jealous of Yehuda, and Yehuda shall not distress Efriam.” These two tribes were always opposing each other, for the force of life which the blessed God gave to Efriam (from Yosef) was of the nature that it always looked to every action regarding its judgment and law, without moving from it. Therefore, when the writings warn Israel against sinning, then the aim of the Torah will be to say (Amos, 5:6), “lest the house of Yosef should prevail like fire,” meaning that they should concern themselves that there should be no opponents to their actions. The root of life for Yehuda, however, is to look to the blessed God regarding the course of every action. Even though he sees where the judgment leans, still he looks to the blessed God in order to see the depth of the truth of the matter.

So it is with all matters, and this is the root of life for Yehuda, to look to God in everything and not to act simply in a way that is accepted or habitual. Even though yesterday he acted in such a way, yet anyhow, today he does not want to rely on his former response, only that the blessed God should illuminate His will into him anew. This matter sometimes necessitates even doing something against the law, for, “it is a time to do for God, the Torah has been suspended.” (Tehillim 119:126)

So upon understanding this, one must be flexible with the will of God, for the vessel only illuminates from that which is shined into it. For the Mei HaShiloach, this is the essence of the commandment concerning the scriptural commandment of temporary vows, as explained in Parshat Mattot:

It occurred [with all of the prophets other than Moshe] in their prophetic spirit that whichever particular word of prophecy they were speaking was enduring for all eternity. Yet truly, there existed changes according to the quality of each generation. On this, “Moshe Rabeynu’s level of prophecy was superior to them all, prophesizing with ‘this is the word.’ ” This means that he understood the prophecy according to its time and place, understanding that a prophecy is only relevant for a particular time, and later God may desire something else … Therefore it is said, “this is the word,” for one must understand that the particular action is only temporarily forbidden to him, and that the blessed God can give him the power to receive all the good of the world without being disconnected from the service of the Divine.

Then, if God’s plans require different processes and limitations for each individual, this changes the way one will view another’s way of acting in the world. “The blessed God allotted to each one goodness and life, and one is not similar to his fellow” (Parshat Bamidbar). In Parshat Va’etchanan:

As for the meaning behind the commandments, each one feels the unique meaning of a commandment that another does not feel, nor does he have the understanding of his fellow. We find an example of this in the Gemara (Pesachim, 53b), “even though one says to light, and another says not to light, they both had the same intention.”6 For at first it seemed as if one disagreed with the other, yet truly there was no disagreement for they both intended the same thing. Thus one does not call to question the attributes of his fellow, for he understands that his fellow can only keep the mitzvah in his own way, and not in his way. Therefore it says (in verse 19), “to cast out all your enemies from before you,” which is referring to those involved in fierce disagreements in Israel. Yet the meaning is not that they should be destroyed, God forbid, but rather to cast out their kind of service from before you, so as not to disturb you from your own service.
Furthermore, the Isbitser reevaluates the entire matter of the commandment to rebuke ones neighbor in his interpretation of the verse, “you shall surely rebuke,” in Parshat Behar:

Even though the blessed God commanded man to reprove his neighbor and to try to distance him from all evil as much as is possible, this is only possible in a place where he knows he can help him by bringing him to the good, or through prayer which will arouse compassion upon him to return him to the path of ethical behavior. However, if he cannot remove him from his errors, then he must judge him meritoriously, and not accuse him. Thus one cannot judge his neighbor as guilty, for perhaps his neighbor’s yetser hara (inclination to evil) is greater than his own. Or, perhaps what he sees as an error or sin is actually permitted to his neighbor, for there are many things that are forbidden to one but permitted to another.

Once one has gone through this process of personal refinement, and refining the way he sees the world, he is capable of experiencing redemption. This is because the nature of exile is really the exile of man’s consciousness, when he cannot see the presence of God in his life. But if he can remove the veil and see how “all really is in the hands of Heaven,” then no matter what transpires, it is all part of the direct involvement of God in order to bring about redemption, where the knowledge of God is sensed with utmost clarity. The classic example of this is found in Parshat Vayigash, where a simple change of consciousness in a second can bring Yehuda from believing that he is facing a life of incarceration by a foreign king to standing before his lost brother who will save his entire family from famine and be reunited with his father:

For all these verses [at the beginning of the Parsha] are a claim against the blessed God, with Yehuda supposing all the while that he was standing before and arguing with a Gentile king. Then when the blessed God sent them the salvation, then they saw that even in retrospect they were never in danger, for truly they were arguing with their brother. Thus it will be in the future, when the blessed God will save us and redeem us, then God will show us that we were never in exile, and that a foreign nation never ruled over us, only God alone. This is the meaning of the verse (Tehillim, 37:10), “and a little more, and there is no evil one, and you considered his place, and there is nothing there,” meaning that very soon evil will be banished. “And you considered,” meaning the understanding of the heart, for if you want to understand its place, “there is nothing there,” meaning that in it there was no power of governance over you.

In this way, redemption is just a change of consciousness. To do this is a difficult path, requiring constant reevaluation of how God’s will illuminates into each one of us. No matter what I think I understand, I have to go back and look again, for every letter in the Torah is infinite, and, as the Mei HaShiloach tells us, there is a depth far deeper in the words of Torah than the human consciousness can conceive.
Betsalel Philip Edwards
Old City, Jerusalem
intro.ftnote: 1. This story is taken from “b’heichal Isbitza—Lublin” (“In the chamber of Isbitza—Lublin”) by S. Z. Shragai, p. 8. “B’ntive: Isbitz—Radzin” by S. Z. Shragai, p. 8, Mossad Harav Kook, 1972.
2. In the tradition of Torah scholars, Reb Mordechai Yosef is called by the name of his book, as the “Mei HaShiloach.”

4. Introduction to Vol. 2 of the Mei HaShiloach. This phrase appears but once in all of Scripture; in Yeshaya (Isaiah) 8:6, “for as much as the the people refuse the waters of Shiloah that flow slowly, and rejoice in R’tsin and the son of Remaliyahu.”
5. I heard this from the mouth of Reb Shlomo Carlebach, z’l.

6. This is discussing whether or not to leave a candle lit on the eve of Yom Kippur. One says that if there is light he is less likely to engage in intimate relations, and another says if it is dark and he does not see his wife, then he will be less likely to succumb. Both opinions are in order to distance one from sin.

ack.title: ACKNOWLEDGMENTS
ack.p: First and foremost I would like to thank the Master of Heaven and Earth who made it possible for this exceptional figure in spiritual history to exist and for me to be able to bring it to the English-speaking public. May He continue to help all of us and take joy in all of our endeavors. Next I must thank my dear wife Ilana who made it possible for me to sit and complete the work now before you, and my dear son Ilai who is a constant source of nachat ruach and inspiration.

In terms of the understanding of the teachings of Isbitza, I am greatly dedicated to Rabbi Shlomo Carlebach, may his memory bless us all, who first passed the fire of the Mei HaShiloach into my heart, and who exemplified its message in every moment of his life. I owe great gratitude to Professor Elie Wiesel, who first introduced me to the teachings of Isbitza and so many other hasidic Masters as a student in his seminar at Boston University. May he continue to inspire us and spread the light of Hasidut throughout the world. I will always be indebted to Dr. Elie Stillman, a hidden master of the Mei HaShiloach, for our discussions of the meaning of these teachings and for just being a good friend. I would like to thank Daniel Langerman of the Talner Community in Boston for presenting me on his visit to Israel with the copy of the Mei HaShiloach from which I translated. And a very special thanks and much gratitude to Arthur Kurzweil, Hope Breeman, and the entire staff of Jason Aronson for the superb production of this volume of the Mei HaShiloach, the first-ever translation of the work into English.

intro.p: A note on the proper pronunciation of the transliterated Hebrew. “Ch” is always a soft guttural as in the German “Nacht” or the Scottish “Loch.” It is never pronounced in a hard palatal as in “chance” or “choke.” The “im” at the end of a word is prounounced “eem,” as in “deem” or “seem.” Thus the name for the book of Kings, for example, is pronounced “Melacheem,” with the “ch” being soft.

intro.title: INTRODUCTION
intro.p: from the “Dor Yesharim” (The Generation of the Upright)

The following is translated from the Dor Yesharim, or Generation of the Upright,1 the family history of Reb Mordechai Yosef z’l and his descendants, written by Chaim Simcha Lainer z’l, a direct descendant of the holy Isbitser. It was published in Lublin, Poland, in 1925.

Lend your ears, and hear that which you have not heard before, the wonders of our master, father, and teacher, the holy Rav, Mordechai Yosef, may his memory be a blessing, the author of the holy book, Mei HaShiloach, the waters of Siloah, may his merits protect us. He upheld the Torah out of poverty, bearing all suffering and all manner of hardship in order to study God’s law. Even in the days of his greatness he did not adorn his home with riches, with the plunder of fine rugs and curtains, but rather made do with little. His main purpose was to let the wellsprings of wisdom flow forth. He soon succeeded in raising many scholars, and after the passing of the holy Rav Simcha Bunem of Pshiske through the influence of the splendor of his torah and Kedusha, he became the main on the spirit of those who seek Hashem. He taught them to go on the path of the just and ways of righteousness. He was the great tree, the Rav of Rabbis, from which sprouted endless branches that instilled the roots of hasidut in those who seek Hashem and His Torah. Among his students were holy ones, geniuses, the truly virtuous, who illuminated the face of the earth with their torah, the light of which appeared upon them in his house of study, as is known. His holy community was like the fellowship of Rabbi Shimon bar Yochai, like that of the holy Baal Shem Tov and our holy master Reb Dov Ber, may their memories be for a blessing. If one tried to tell all of his good deeds, wonders, and the holy ways in which he went in the span of his short life, then “the curtain in the chamber of the Holy Temple would not suffice.” Yet we may say that he brought salvation, rescue, and redemption in both matters physical and spiritual, for the mute and the destitute. He increased Torah and strength, bringing many souls under the wings of the Shechina. Great were his actions, effects, and way of holy service that he paved for the sake of God’s glory. And great is the honor that the Omnipresent has granted him forever.

In his youth, he was a student in the town of Tomashov. The holy Rav, our master and teacher Reb Menachem Mendel, may his memory be for a blessing,2 of Kotsk was also a student in that town, and both were hasidim of the Prshisker Rebbe. Between them there was love and friendship and peace. It once happened that there was a dispute in the house of study between the hasidim of Pshiske and the hasidim of another court. The dispute came to blows, and the Rav, Reb Menachem Mendel z’l was then in the house of study. Someone went to notify Reb Mordechai Yosef z’l, who was still at his home. When he heard, he ran directly to the house of study. On his way, when someone on the side of the road saw a Pshisker hasid racing in the street, he knew immediately that he was going to help the Pshiskers. So then the man extended his leg in front of the shins of my grandfather3 z’l to cause him to fall. He then tripped, and then got immediately on his feet, continuing on his way. The man who tripped him immediately began to feel pain in his leg, and soon after was confined to bed. He could never walk again, and was bedridden until the day of his death some twenty years later. So would one be careful of his wrath.

After the passing of the holy Rav, Reb Simcha Bunem, z’l, of Pshiske, who was his brilliant teacher and the one who laid hands on his head, all of his hasidim looked to Mordechai Yosef, z’l, in order to establish him as their leader. They looked to him to teach them the ways of Torah and hasidut, and the service of God, to place the holy crown on his head and call him “Rebbe,” for they knew his greatness. Yet it was not yet the time for him to take upon himself the position of the rabbinate. This is as he said himself at this time, telling them to choose a Rebbe from whoever was fit in their eyes, and I too will be together with you in this appointment, until the year 5600, for then I too will be a Rebbe, with the help of the blessed God, and a shepherd a community of Israel. When they heard this they chose Reb Menachem Mendel z’l for their Rebbe, and Mordechai Yosef joined with them in the community of Kotsk.
Among all of the hasidim in Kotsk he was esteemed as a holy man, where no one exceeded the height of his stature. They relegated him great honor for his pure and authentic torah and service.

One time in Kotsk, the holy genius Yitsik Meir z’l, the “Chiddushei Harim,” entered into his room to speak with him for a great while. He was lying on his bed and the “Harim” z’l was sitting at his feet. Eventually he fell asleep, and in the midst of his sleep he placed his feet on the knees of the “Harim” z’l. The Harim z’l did not move an inch until my grandfather z’l woke from his sleep on his own accord. In this way all of the great ones of the generation would honor him.

Once while he was still with his Rav (the Pshisker z’l) a scholarly man came to visit from some famous city. They had said of him that he could recite all of the six orders of the Mishna by heart. When the hasidim told Reb Mordechai Yosef z’l, he answered, “like me? I too can recite all of the Mishnayot by heart.” They began to test him, and of each place that they asked him, he answered immediately without stuttering. This was a wonder in their eyes, for they had never known that he had this ability. So he answered them, “why does this amaze you? I did not learn them so I could later brag to you that I could say them all by heart! Just in the course of my study I manage to remember them, as it is written, and Your Torah is in my belly’ (Tehillim, 40:9). This is as it is written in the Tanna D’vei Eliyahu (Rabba, Ch. 2), ‘Fortunate is the man who places himself like an ox under the yoke, and like a mule carrying a load. Who each day, constantly, sits and contemplates the Torah. Immediately the Holy Spirit will rest upon him, and the Torah will be in his belly.’ ” This principle was upheld by my grandfather, z’l, and all of the hasidim in Kotsk and Pshiske saw this.

He had exhibited the clear spirit of prophecy on numerous occasions. Once when he was still in Kotsk, the time came for him to travel to his hometown. When he went in to receive the blessing of the Rebbe z’l, the Rebbetzin said to him, “Soon I will give birth. Maybe you could stay a little longer until the brit mila?” He immediately answered her, “you will certainly give birth to a girl.” The Rebbetzin told this to the Rebbe, and he answered her, “if he said it, it will surely be.” And so it was.

On another occasion it happened that he needed to travel to his hometown. When he went in to receive the blessing from the Rebbe, the Rebbetzin told him just as was mentioned above. He then answered her, “You will give birth to twins, and by the time of the brit I will, God willing, have returned to Kotsk.” And it happened just as he had said.

When the time had come to reveal his great light in the year 5600 from the creation of the world, the year hinted at when the holy Zohar says, “the gates of wisdom will be opened” (as is cited in the shalshelet haqabbalah), he then spent the holidays from Rosh Hashanah until after Succot in Kotsk, as had been his custom. This time, immediately after Rosh Hashanah, many of the hasidim began to crown him with the title “Rebbe.” Some then gave him “Kvitlach”4 and “Pidyonos.”5 A storm of controversies and opposing views ensued among the hasidim. Jealousy dwells even in high places. However, the God-fearing and scholarly hasidim sided with him, cleaving unto him. Thus was the atmosphere in Kotsk until Shmini Atseret,6 and the Rebbe did not say a word. On the eve of Shmini Atseret, my grandfather z’l told the hasidim in his charge to bring Torah scrolls to his lodgings, where they would pray and dance with the Torah separate from the festivities in the house of study of the Rebbe z’l. They did as he said at once, though at this time did not understand his reasons for this request. After several hours, the Rebbe z’l was praying in his room in the house of study, and his hasidim were making dancing circuits with the Torah scrolls. My grandfather z’l had each year been appointed to lead the sixth hakafa (dancing circuit) of “Yosef haTsaddik.”7 When they had arrived at this hakafa, the Rebbe z’l ran from his room adjacent to the house of study and snatched the Torah scroll from the one who was holding it. He then immediately raised his eyes to look in the face of the one from whom he had taken the Torah scroll, and returned it, saying that he had thought that he was my grandfather z’l. Seeing this, the hasidim then understood that in his prophetic spirit he had prepared a separate order of dancing in his lodgings, in order to avoid certain controversy. My grandfather z’l said that if at that moment he had been holding the Torah scroll, there is no way it could have been taken from him. After the incident, Reb Mordechai Yosef z’l told his hasidim that he had received a hint from heaven not to go to the hakafot in the house of study. That morning, in confusion, his shoes had been switched and he had put his left shoe on his right foot. From this he had understood not to go, but rather arrange the dancing in his lodgings.

After that, when he went to travel back to his home town of Tomashov, Reb David z’l, the son of the (Kotsker) Rebbe z’l, went to accompany him on his way out of town, to the place where he met his wagon. Reb David z’l said, “what can you give me as a souvenir?” So he gave him all of the Kvitlach that the hasidim had given him during the High Holy Days. He said to him, “I leave you with a livelihood for your children and children’s children.” Many years later, Reb David z’l said that with this, he made Reb Mordechai Yosef z’l his Rebbe. He sent the money of all the Pidyonot to the Rebbetzin (of Kotsk) and made his way on to Tomashov. He then began to act according to his new status on high (as a Rebbe), and people were drawn to him from near and far. He increased in the study of Torah and the ways of hasidut. Then, everyone for whom the fear of God touched his heart, and to whom God had granted a heart of understanding, would drink thirstily from his holy words, which flowed from the source of life. It was then that he established his home in the town of Isbitza, outside of Lublin, fulfilling the words of the Chozei z’l (Seer) of Lublin. For it was, that once the holy Rebbe, our teacher Yaakov Yitschok z’l, the Rav of Lublin, called the Chozei, had passed through the town of Isbitza. He had said that this town was similar to Jerusalem, the holy city, for “Jerusalem, mountains surround her” (Tehillim, 125:2), and finished by saying that here would someday be a great scholar who would disseminate the knowledge of the Torah of Truth among the many.

He was a “sage, preferable to a prophet.” He had a clear and refined intuition. Once, on Rosh Hashanah, among the congregation of hasidim, there was a certain hasid, a man of Torah and the fear of God, who began to have regrets about having traveled to Isbitza for Rosh Hashanah. He thought, “maybe I should have traveled to a Rebbe who is not beset by opponents.” Immediately another thought came to his mind, thinking, “is it not forbidden to question the attributes of one’s Rav?” From this thought sprang another thought. “Whoever said he is my Rav?” In this way his thoughts and musings flashed through his mind to such an extent that he could not bring himself any sound counsel. Finally, he decided to wait for a sign. If he saw that the Rebbe feels his thoughts, then he would know that he is the true tsaddik of the generation, and the Rebbe whose torah should be sought after, for he is an angel of the Lord of Hosts.

Then it was, after Rosh Hashanah, when this man came before my grandfather z’l, he began speaking to the man, saying, “It is written in the Torah, ‘keep the festival of matsot.’ You should know that the scholar is called ‘the festival,’ and the matsot means strife, contention, and controversy.8 This is the explanation of ‘the festival of matsot.’ The scholar who is embroiled in strife, contention, and controversy, this is the very one you should keep and bring yourself close to.” In saying this, he had solved the man’s dilemma before him. He now knew that his Rav was an angel of the Lord of Hosts, and he traveled to be with him all the days of his life.

Once when he was in Isbitza sitting at his holy table among his devoted followers on the festival of Shevuot, he suddenly told his hasidim to take his table and chairs outside to the river’s edge. They did not understand why he wanted this. Then after the festival, a man came to Isbitza and told how that Shevuot he had been with the Rebbe of Kotsk. The Rebbe asked the man to describe the exact location and position of the Kotsker z’l’s holy table. The man described its proper location. Then they saw that with his prophetic spirit he had immediately felt this, thereby immediately changing his location.

One time on the holy day of Shabbos in the middle of his repast he asked the hasidim sitting with him to stand around him, and on the benches. He told them to bend their heads over the table from both sides in order to cover the table with a kind of succa. Later he told them that he had asked them to do this because of the situation between him and the Rebbe of Kotsk z’l.

The holy Rav, our teacher, Reb Yitsik z’l of Vorke, once passed through the town of Isbitza. My grandfather z’l asked him to spend the holy Shabbos with him. He answered him and said, “With all my heart and soul I would like to spend Shabbos with you, for surely I will experience much greater light and Kedusha with you than at the place where I am now going. But what can I do? I am obligated to go on my way.” With this he received a blessing on his departure from the Rebbe z’l with apologies and great love.

In the town of Isbitza he had his opponents. Once on the holy Shabbos one of his opponents, an arrogant miscreant, had the audacity to enter the kitchen where Rebbe’s Shabbos food was stored, opened the stove, and mixed dirt in with the food. When the Rebbe’s shammash came in to get the food, he saw what had happened, and could not serve the food because it had become foul and impossible to eat. Meanwhile the Rebbe asked why the food was not being brought to the table, and the shammash was too embarrassed to answer. After the Rebbe asked a few times he was told the truth, that someone had come in and deliberately ruined the food and that it was now inedible. When he heard this, he instructed them to bring the food to the table as it was, and immediately the food fouled with earth was brought before him. He saw this, and then opened his holy mouth, saying to those sitting before him, “What is fitting to do with a man who in impunity spoils and shames food fit for human consumption? And all the more so, food for the holy Shabbos? And even more so, food prepared for Torah scholars? Therefore he who put dust in the food should be made into ashes and dust. (Heaven save us.)” And so it was. To this day, there are those in Isbitza who remember this event, how after this Shabbos the hand of Hashem went forth and struck the miscreant and his household with severe judgments, Heaven help us. Beware of His wrath.

Among the holy community of my grandfather z’l were two particularly noteworthy students. One was our holy Rav, Ariye Leib Eiger z’l, famous for his great sanctity, chastity, and piety. He was truly dedicated to the service of the Divine, and sacrificed himself to these ends all the days of his life. The second was our holy and great Rav, Tsadok haCohen z’l of Lublin. Besides his sanctity, righteousness, and piety, he was also known as a genius, fiery and expert in the chambers of the Torah. There was no one like him in his time, as we see now that his many awesome writings have been made available. These two students themselves attest that they never reached even the border of the righteousness and Divine service of their Rav, nor the excellence and greatness of his scholarship in Torah. At that time the sages of this generation said that this is how one can recognize the true greatness and Kedusha of the Rebbe. For how great and exalted is the Rebbe whose righteousness and service of God exceeds even Reb Leibale Eiger z’l, and whose wisdom, greatness, and fierceness in Torah exceeds even Reb Tsadok haCohen z’l! These two went to ask of the ways of Torah from his mouth. Certainly he is angel of the Lord of Hosts.

The holy Rav, our teacher Tsadok haCohen z’l of Lublin testified of him that in all his days he never spoke of idle or mundane matters, and all his words require study, as they were filled with the knowledge of Torah.
My uncle, the holy Rav, our teacher Gershon Chenoch Hainich z’l once said to me, “Zein Treit hot gebrent mit divrei Torah—all of his very footsteps burned with the words of Torah!”

His custom was to study every night in the house of study with his hasidim. First the shammash would come to the house of study with two candles and a tractate of the Gemara, signaling to the hasidim that the lesson would soon begin. Then everyone prepared his place. Then the Rebbe z’l would immediately arrive and sit in his place also, where he would commence to teach about a page of the Gemara or more. Afterward he would say “Chidushei Torah,” original insights into the Torah on the subjects that they were studying. It was like this every night. This was also the custom with my grandfather, the holy Rav, our teacher Yaakov z’l, in Isbitza and later in the town of Radzin. All the skins of all the deer would not suffice to record in writing all of the wisdom that was said there, and so too it was not the students’ custom to write, but each would take mental notes according to his understanding.

One time he said to his hasidim, “You are to know that whoever travels to me, at the time that he is with me he forgets his home completely. This is a sign that he has some connection to me. And one who is with me and remembers his home, he has no connection to me. You are all to know that I see each one of you in particular. I see even that which you do in you innermost chambers, and in secret in your homes.”
It was his custom before the morning shacharit prayer to recite verses from Parshat Ha’azinu (Devarim, Ch. 32). Those who knew of this would also follow this custom.
As is known, when dressing one always dresses first the right side, and then the left. Once it happened that he put on his left shoe first. For this he fasted and did not speak the entire day.

It was his custom after taking a hot bath in honor of the Shabbos or a festival for his shammash to pour pure olive oil on his head. Our master and teacher z’l the “Beit Yaakov” (his son), also followed this custom after him.

One time, on the eve of the holy Shabbos (Friday afternoon) while walking home from the bathhouse of the town of Isbitza down the main street, he saw a small child sitting by the window of a house. When he passed by the window he heard the child say, “the wicked stray from the womb” (Tehillim, 58:4), for he (the child) noticed some impunity in him. May the blessed God give us and all of Israel children God has blessed.

At the time of the plague, Heaven protect us, he commanded to say constantly the verse (Tehillim, 94:22), “Hashem shall be my stronghold, God shall be the rock of my refuge,” for in this verse are contained all forces of success and protection.

Once it happened that a woman on the verge of giving birth entered alone into a barn, and disappeared. They searched for her but could not find her. After a great search, towards evening, they found her lying cast down by a river. When they asked her how she had gotten there, she said that they had forced her from the barn and taken her to the river. There they placed her in the water, and as she was about to expire from drowning, an elder appeared and said to them, “let her go, have mercy on her, she has yet to live.” Just after the elder had said this, her assailants removed her from the river and placed her on the bank, soaked through. (When the search party found her), they took her to her house and put her in her bed. Then on the second day, at exactly the time when they had taken her from the barn to the river, she girded her strength and ran from her bed, saying that she had to get to the river. With all her strength she fought with the men who did not let her run away, and it continued in this way each day until she was nearly completely insane with harrowing phantasms. They went and told my grandfather z’l about the situation. He told them to write a kosher mezuzah and to hang it around her neck. So they did, and she returned to her senses, with evil no longer terrifying her, God forbid.
The Rebbe z’l once advised the use of a segula9 for one sick with jaundice to place a living dove on the stomach of the man. The dove took the sickness inside her and the man was healed.

He would never eat meat that was slaughtered and cooked in the same day. Rather he requested that it be cooked the day after it was slaughtered. There is a source for this both in the wisdom of the kabbalah and in ways of good health.

He once said during an extended study of the tractate Eruvin in the Gemara, that it is a good segula to study each Shabbos eve a certain selection from this tractate (Eruvin, 21a), Rav Chisda said, Rav Mari bar Mar explained, ‘why is it written (Tehillim, 119), “for every purpose I have seen and end, Your commandments are exceedingly broad’ ” until, we find that the whole cosmos is one in three thousand two hundredths of the span of the Torah.”

One time, during the week of the Torah reading Tetsave, as he was sitting by his table on the holy Shabbos, he gave a certain man a flask of wine and said, “it is written in this week’s Parsha (Shemot, 28:13), ‘and you shall make settings of gold.’ Zalst haben felleh kastlich mit gold.—May you have crates filled with gold!’ ” Some days later, it happened that this man won the lottery, and became immensely wealthy.

Once a group of Kleizmorim (musicians) came to the Rebbe. They complained that a certain Baron had planned a great feast with music, and had invited them. Already expecting their wages from the Baron, they prepared themselves to play at the feast, when they heard that a group of Gentile musicians had approached the Baron, and winning his favor, the Baron had canceled the Jewish musicians. This caused them great damage and shame, for these were Kleizmorim of a high level who pleased all that heard them. When he heard this, his compassion for them was aroused, and he rested his head on his arm for some moments. When he arose, all who stood before him saw that tears were streaming down his face. He said to them, “do not fear. You will yet play for the Baron, and he will even ask your forgiveness.” Thus it was, that at the time of the feast when the Gentile musicians began to play, the Baron heard all kinds of mistakes in their playing, as he had an understanding of music. They also did not please the guests. He immediately fired them and sent for the Kleizmorim, appeasing them and giving them a great salary. The Baron and all of the guests were thoroughly enraptured in their music. It was then that they saw that the words of the Rebbe were the words of the living God.

It once happened that a certain hasid who was close to him fell from his position into poverty, Heaven protect us, until he did not even have the means to support his family. He then traveled to my grandfather z’l and poured before him his bitter predicament. He pleaded for the Rebbe to help him and the children in his care. The Rebbe advised him to travel to Lublin, and there he would find salvation. The man immediately took his advice, traveling to Lublin with only a few pennies in his pocket. There he milled about the streets and markets, but found no sign of assistance. About two weeks after he had come to Lublin, he was in the street, and he saw a Polish army officer walking toward him. When the officer saw him, he asked him, “are you the one whose name is (such and such)?” “Yes, sir,” answered the hasid. “Then come to my house tonight. I have something for you.” He then gave the hasid a card with his name and address written on it, and went on his way. The hasid asked around about the identity of this officer, and someone told him that he was the captain of a new regiment that had recently come to this area, but before that he was in the town of (such and such). Upon hearing the name of the town, the hasid remembered that he had a brother in that very same town whose name and family name was that which the officer had mentioned when he saw that the hasid was related to him. That night, when the hasid went to the officer’s house, he saw many men knocking on his door. The officer refused them all entry, save the hasid, whon he took into his storeroom. There he gave him enough food and provisions for an entire regiment, as if he was his own brother. He also gave him money. When he left the house, the crowd saw him with all the boxes of supplies, and before he left he had sold them all he had. The man became rich and lived well the rest of his life.

Once during the week of Parshat Shlach, he explained why the incident of sending the spies is immediately followed by the commandment of the wine libations and the challot (showbreads) in the temple. In his pure language, that it is the way of the world and men that if someone is weak, suffering, or anguished you give him a glass of wine and food to give him strength. This is as it is written (Mishlei, 31), “give wine to the bitter of spirit.” So, too, after the mission of the spies, when all of Israel became depressed, and mourned greatly over the decree that they would not enter the land of Israel. So therefore they were given the mitzvot of the libations and challa. “A trink branfin mit far bissen—a drink of liquor with a little snack.”

Once during Parshat Vayigash, he said the notakarion10 of “Vayigash (meaning ‘and he {Yehuda} came close to {to Yosef}’)” (from Bereshit, 44:18) was Vint Yudilech givent shreit—“the Jews cried a terrible cry.” The Rebbe z’l himself passed away in the week of Parshat Vayigash. So did my uncle (the Isbitzer’s grandson) the Rav Gershon Chenoch Hainich z’l pass away during Parshat Vayigash. Once, the holy Rav and disciple of the Isbitser, our teacher Reb Tsadok haCohen z’l, wrote in his book, Pri, that he himself once heard the Rebbe z’l say that crying was hinted at in the word “Vayigash—and he came close,” and that there was a great and deep matter in this.

Once during Parshat Vayikra he said, “When I learned the verses (Vayikra, 2:5-6) ‘And if your sacrifice is a meal offering baked in a pan, it shall be of fine unleavened flour mixed with oil. You shall crumble it into pieces, and pour onto it oil—it is a meal offering,’ then I felt the smell of life.” I counted the number of words in these two verses, and they came to eighteen, the numerical equivalent of chai, “alive.” I then counted the number of letters in these two verses, and I arrived at sixty-eight, the numerical equivalent of chaiim, “life.”

[My uncle, the holy Rav, Reb Moshe Chaim Sokachevski z’l of Chelm, showed me another verse in this vein. It is (Devarim, 23:6), “and Hashem your God did not desire to listen to Bilaam, so for you Hashem your God turned his curse into a blessing, for Hashem your God loves you.” In this verse there are also eighteen words and sixty-eight letters equivalent to chaiim—“life.”]

Once on Rosh Hashanah before the sounding of the Shofar he instructed all of the hasidim who were in the house of study to recite from the blessing directly before the morning Shema the words, “With eternal love have you loved us, Hashem our God,” until just before the end of the blessing, “and to unify You with love, and to love Your name,” three times. He said that he saw a great spirit of accusation descending upon Israel in the coming year, and therefore they were to pray with special fervor and return to God’s ways from the depths of their hearts. He himself recited this with tears. And indeed, that year the harsh decrees were renewed against Israel, may Heaven protect us.

His disciple the holy Rav, the genius Reb Tsadok haCohen z’l, took upon himself as a custom, and each year before the sounding of the Shofar, he commanded the congregation to recite “with an eternal love” three times.

In his days, a certain famous astrologer made a great tumult by saying that in a few more months a comet would destroy the world. Many believed him and feared his words. When this was told to the Rebbe z’l, he said that these were pure lies, for it is written (Amos, 3:7), “Hashem E-lohim will not do anything that he does not reveal to his servants the prophets.” He said, “How could a thing like this be true in the world and Hashem did not reveal it to me? Therefore it is all lies, and you shall not believe it.”

He passed away with a good name in the year 5614, on the seventh day of the month of Tevet. His final resting place was in the town of Isbitza, and he left behind him the blessing of words of Torah in his holy book, the Mei HaShiloach, in two volumes. There are also many more of his words in writing and passed on from mouth to ear between men of standing. May God bring us life and His merit protect us. Amen. Let it be His will.
Love of Israel was fixed permanently in his heart, to such a great extent that he warned against bringing accusations, God forbid, even against sinners. These are his words in the Mei HaShiloach:
“And you shall not wrong one another, and you shall fear your God ….” (Vayikra, 25:17).

This verse is also directed to great souls of precious value, when they see someone doing something against the will of the blessed God, and want to accuse against him, punishing him. On this the Holy One, blessed be He, “do not wrong,” and similarly did David haMelech say (Tehillim, 50:20–21, following R. Hirsch’s translation), “You sit and speak against your brother, you slander your own mother’s son. You have done these things; and I stood by in silence, so you thought I was the same as you. Therefore I will reprove you, and set them in order before your eyes.” “You sit and speak against your brother, you slander your own mother’s son” means that he does so even though he is obliged to love his neighbor, as is commanded of him (Vayikra, 19:18), “you shall love your neighbor as yourself.” Man must ask in his prayers for compassion toward his fellow man, but still, he wants to bring accusations against him.

Therefore the Blessed God says, “you have done these things, and I stood by in silence.” If the blessed God sees fit to clarify matters, then even the actions of the Tsaddikim will not be meritorious in His eyes, for in the presence of the blessed God who can justify himself, and who can say, “I have refined my heart”? And still, the blessed God is silent, not revealing the shame of any man even if he shall sin. You thought that I was the same as you,” for he who brings accusations against his fellow man considers himself and his actions as refined as the will of the blessed God. He believes wholeheartedly that it is the will of the blessed God that he should accuse the man who sins. To this grave error the blessed God says, “Therefore I will reprove you, and set them in order before your eyes.”

This means that the blessed God will show truth to the face of he who points to the guilt of his neighbor and says that it is God’s will that he do so. God reproves him by showing that the will of the blessed God is only to conceal all the sins of Israel. Thus is it written (Micha, 7:19), “and cast all their sins to the depths of the sea.” Thus He will conceal them greatly so they will not be revealed and never more seen. So how could one say that the blessed God wants us to expose the guilt of our neighbors, expanding upon their sins? Even though the blessed God commanded man to reprove his neighbor and to try to distance him from all evil as much as is possible, this is only possible in a place where he knows he can help him by bringing him to the good, or through prayer that will arouse compassion upon him to return him to the path of ethical behavior. However, if he cannot remove him from his errors, then he must judge him meritoriously, and not accuse him. Thus one cannot judge his neighbor as guilty, for perhaps his neighbor’s yetser hara (inclination to evil) is greater than his own. Or, perhaps what he sees as an error or sin is actually permitted to his neighbor, for there are many things that are forbidden to one but permitted to another.
On the same subject, also in Parshat Behar, it says the following: “A man who sells his house in a walled city,” etc. (Vayikra, 25:29)

The passage dealing with houses in walled cities teaches that man knows that all the matters of the Yovel are in order to make it clear that there is a time for everything. Even if a man sinned against the blessed God, He will not be angry with him forever. This passage teaches that such a situation only arises when a man sins in affairs between him and the Omnipresent. Although this arouses the attribute of stern judgment where he must sell from his portion or be sold as a servant, it shall not be so forever, for he will go out in the Yovel, and a man shall return to his portion. However, a man may arouse the attribute of stern judgment from a sin between man and his fellow man, with the main example of this being if a man sins by shaming his fellow man publicly with his words. This is what the verse meant when it said, “if a man shall sell his house in a walled city,” for the tongue is called “a house in a walled city,” as it says (Arachin, 15b), “I have given you two walls [the lips].” By means of this a man could, God forbid, sell and lose all his merits, and his fellow man could buy them. On this Shlomo haMelech said (Mishlei, 25:28), “He who cannot control his own spirit is like a city with its walls broken down.”11 The advice given for this is to reconcile with his fellow man within a year, and on this it says, “for a full year he shall have the right of redemption.” “And if it not be redeemed within the space of a full year, then the house that is in the walled city shall be established forever to him that bought it throughout the generations,” meaning that if he does not reconcile with his fellow man, then his merits will permanently remain with his fellow. This is the explanation of the difference between how the verse is spelled in the Torah scroll and how it is read. “The house that is in the walled city” or “the house that has a wall” is written in Hebrew, “asher lo homa.” Lo is written in Hebrew Lamed Aleph, which would mean “does not have a wall.” However, we read it as if it were written as Lamed Vav, “which has a wall.” The meaning is that a man who has no control over his spirit is called “without a wall,” and the one who controls his spirit is called one “with a wall.” Thus it is that all the merits of one who cannot control his spirit will remain in the possession of the one who could control his spirit and remained silent.
intro.ftnote: 1. See Tehillim, 112:2, “The generation of the upright will be blessed.”
2. Henceforth the customary mention of “may his memory be for a blessing,” after the name of a great Rav who is no longer in this world will be abbreviated with z’l, for zichrono livrocha.
3. The author was a direct descendant of Reb Mordechai Yosef z’l after five generations. When I write “my grandfather,” rendered from z’keni, bear in mind that “my great-great grandfather” is meant.

4. It is the custom among some hasidic communities for the hasid to write his request on a piece of paper and give it to his Rebbe, to pray over the request and advise the hasid. This written request is called a Kvittle (pl. Kvitlach). Kvitlach are even left at the graves of great hasidic Rebbes, in order that the soul of the Rebbe intercede in heaven on behalf of the hasid.

5. A “Pidyon,” (pl. Pidyonos) is a gift of some value given to the Rebbe by a hasid in a time of need, through which in the act of reception the Rebbe prays for the welfare of the one giving it. The ancient belief is that it is decreed that the one giving the pidyon must suffer a loss, so the act of giving the gift or money is a transfer of a physical loss for a monetary loss.

6. Shmini Atseret is the eighth day of Succot, marked by dancing with scrolls of the Torah. Seven hakafot or dancing circuits are made around and with the Torah scrolls, each hakafa in honor of one of the seven “shepherds” of Israel: Avraham, Yitschok, Yaakov, Moshe, Aharon, Yosef, and David.

7. The one honored to “lead the hakafa” takes the Torah scroll in his arm, and introduces the dancing by chanting a short liturgy. Then when the singing starts, he dances in the center of the circle for a while with a few other friends, while the rest of the congregation rotates around him in a circle dance. After a while he passes the Torah scroll to another to dance with, and so forth.
8. This is understood from the verse in Mishlei (17:19), “he who loves transgression loves quarrel [matsa].”

9. A segula is a ritual or action reputed to influence a certain good effect, yet with no obvious connection to the good effected. For example, smelling the wick of the havdalla candle after the havdalla ceremony is supposed to save one from anger, or a woman biting off the end of the etrog (citron) with the stem (pitom) after Succot is a segula for her to become pregnant, and there are countless others that are supposed to influence health and success.

10. Notakarion is the system in which a word is an abbreviation of the first or last letters of a phrase or verse. Thus one can make esoteric connections otherwise hidden. For example, “Shabbat,” is an abbreviation of the last letters of the verse erets zavaT chalaV u’devaSH, “a land flowing with milk and honey.”

11. It needs to be noted that the word ruach, “spirit,” can also mean breath, and hence one who refrains from using his breath and voice to shame another. Keep this in mind whenever the phrase “controls his spirit” is used.

chapter.title: PARSHAT BERESHIT
chapter.p: “In the beginning God created ….” (Bereshit, 1:1)

“Created” means strengthening. In the beginning, He strengthened and reinforced the foundations so that they could receive the creation. This is as a king, when he builds his treasure house, he first strengthens the foundations and the walls so they can receive what he places inside it, and the heavens and the earth are the foundations of the universe. They are hinted in man in the brain and the heart. At a time when man wants to proceed according to the will of the blessed God, in order to be a complete facet of creation, then he must invigorate and strengthen these two foundations. In other words, he must deliver over to the blessed God the intellect and thought in the head, and the desires of the heart, and then crown God, may He be blessed, over them, so that they only act according to the will of the blessed God. This is as in the saying of Rabbi Israel, the holy Baal Shem Tov, “where a man’s thoughts are, that is where he is in his entirety.” This is the meaning of the verse in Mishlei (Mishlei, 24:26), “My son, give me your heart,” and then the continuation of the verse follows of itself, that then, “you [your eyes] will want to observe My ways.” This means that when you deliver over your heart to the blessed God, then you will make the service of the blessed God your main occupation, and all the matters of this world will be secondary. This can be understood by means of a parable. A rich man has a wise and wonderful son, whom he betroths to a woman fitting for his honor. At the time when he prepares the wedding banquet and tastes of the food that he prepared, at that moment he remembers the joy of his son, and the taste of the food becomes secondary. Understand this.
“And God said, ‘Let there be light,’ and there was light.” (Bereshit, 1:3)

It is said in the Midrash (Bereshit Rabba, 1:1), “Rabbi Ushaya Rabba opened, (Mishlei, 8:30) ‘And I was as one brought up with him, and I delighted in him each day.’ Ammon, or ‘brought up,’ means like a tutor.1 ‘Ammon,’ he was well covered. ‘Ammon,’ he was hidden [or well cared for]. There are those who say, ‘Ammon,’ the name of the capital (in Egypt, Alexandria was once called ‘Ammon’).2 Another interpretation: ‘Ammon’ is an artisan.” These five interpretations of Ammon are the same as we find in man, for he goes through five states of being and levels from the beginning of his existence until he comes into his final form of completeness.

At first, at the time of conception by the father and mother, he is completely hidden, and not recognizable to any part of creation. The second state of being is once he has been formed in his mother’s womb, then he begins to engender some form of recognition as a separate entity. The third state of being occurs once he is born, and his status as a separate entity is complete, and all can see that he a unique part of creation. The fourth state happens when he is weaned from his mother’s breast and begins to act on his own. The fifth level of being begins when he marries a wife and then begins to create new beings, to be built as an everlasting structure, and toward this end was he created. And thus it is, that these five states of being are found in the creation of the world, which come forth from nothing and the completely hidden to the revealed and substantive.

At first it (the creation) was called “brought up in secret,” for it was included in God’s essence, may He be blessed, and there was no recognition of it emanating from Him, may He be blessed, and this was the first state of being. When the creation emanated from the blessed God, and began to move more toward the revealed, then it was in the second state of being, called “brought up well covered.” This is the secret of the embryonic state, which is well covered. Afterward, it went further into the revealed, called “brought up as by a tutor.” These three states of being are the first three hidden sefirot: Keter (crown), Chochma (wisdom), and Binah (understanding).3 The Midrash explains these three sefirot from below to above. First, “raised as by a tutor” is Binah, and then “raised well covered” is Chochma, and then “raised in secret” is Keter, which because it is so greatly concealed is called “in secret.”

Afterward it revealed itself more, called “ammon the capital” (as the capital is something thoroughly revealed), meaning that the creation began to grow, and this is the secret of being weaned from the mother’s breast. Afterward, “ammon is an artisan,” meaning that the creation emerged into the completely revealed, and (as an artisan) began by itself to bring new beings into the world according to the will of the blessed God. This is why at a wedding we pronounce the blessing “who formed man in His image,” and not at the time of birth. Even though man is born, he is not yet completely perfected; yet rather when he begins to try to make new beings, and this is when he marries a wife.

And this is the meaning of “and the world was tohu u’vohu, chaos and void,” meaning that from the time of conception until the time that the embryo is recognized is called tohu, chaos or unformed. Then from the time it is recognized it is called bohu, void, meaning that we can see that something is there, yet we do not know what it is. The nine months of pregnancy are called “and darkness on the face of the abyss,” because at that time there is an expectation and hope to know the end from this, so therefore it is called “abyss.”4 “And the spirit of God hovered” is the time when the woman is giving birth, for at that time both the mother and the baby are closer to death than life, as is said in the Midrash and Gemara (Vayikra Rabba, 27:7). “And God said, let there be light,” meaning when the salvation is completely finished. Here in these verses, “let there be light” is mentioned five times, corresponding to the five states of being mentioned. The last one is “and God called the light day,” meaning that with this God completed all the intentions He had with which to create the world.
“And God said, let us make a man ….” (Bereshit, 1:26)

This means that from the beginning God created all the creation, and afterward, the creation understood and recognized that it was lacking, for it had no one to connect its vitality to the blessed God. By means of man, all the facets of this world may be connected to the blessed God, for man raises everything up, as is known. The inanimate enters its power into the vegetation, and the vegetation into the animal, and the animal into the speaking (mankind). Then man, since he serves God with his strength, elevates all the powers he received from this world, even from the inanimate. Then when the creation realized how it was lacking, it effected an awakening from below for the creation of man. “God said let us make a man,” in other words (“let us,” for God is addressing all the created beings), the blessed God said to the entire creation that each one should give of its power and join in the creation of man, so that man would then have a portion in all of them. Then if man should need anything they would all stand to help him, for in his evil he could do them harm, as in the generation of the flood, but in his good he could also benefit them.
“And thus the heavens and the earth were completed and all their host.” (Bereshit, 2:1)

The holy Rav of Pshiske, Reb Simcha Bunem, may the mention of the Tsaddik be for a blessing in the world to come (the author’s teacher), said that we have no instance in all of the Torah and Scripture where the creation of the earth is called “host.”5 Yet from the time that the people Israel came into the world, the earth was also made into the name “host.” This is the explanation. A host is a multitude that is united under one who unifies them, such as under a king who rules over all of them together. So in the heavens it is conceivable to use the term “host,” for there His sovereignty and oneness is recognized over the host of Heaven. It is clear that He rules over them and unifies them. Therefore each time it says, “the host of heavens.” Yet in this world, where the idolaters deny the providence of the Holy One, blessed be He, it is inconceivable to use the term “host,” regarding them, rather, “descendent,” (tse’etsaim in Hebrew). Take for instance (Yesahya 42:5), “He has spread forth the earth and all which came out of it [tse’etsaeha],” where “what came out of it” signifies spreading out. Yet when Israel came to the world and recognized that the blessed God rules over all, publicly proclaiming God’s name, then even in this world the land was also called “host.”
“And thus the heavens and the earth were completed and all their host.” (Bereshit, 2:1)

It is written in the Gemara (Shabbat, 119b), “all who say the verse, ‘thus the heavens and the earth were completed,’ are made a partner with the Holy One, blessed be He, in the act of creation.” The matter is, that the main point of the creation of the world was so that Israel could recognize His blessed sovereignty and oneness. In this way Avraham Avinu began to use this new kind of consciousness to call in the name of God, the Lord of the land (not just of the heavens), and each soul in Israel yearns for this. Were it not for this the heavens and the earth would not be able to endure, as we find in the Gemara (Shabbat, 88b), “It would be well for Israel to receive the Torah, for if not this place will be your graves.”6 Whoever recognizes the blessed God’s sovereignty in the world has completed the creation, for here speech is like action. And whoever recognizes the day of Shabbat, and crowns the blessed God over all that He has effected in the six days of creation, even though he is a mere finite and frail mortal compared to the blessed God, nonetheless that man is judged, and the two angels who accompany him, that is, the yetser hara and the yetser tov (the inclination to evil and the inclination to good), place their hands on his head and say to him, “your transgression is removed and your sin is atoned for.”

“And God caused to sprout from the land every tree pleasant to the sight and good to eat, and the tree of life in the midst of the garden, and the tree of the knowledge of good and evil.” (Bereshit, 2:9)

Hinted at in this verse are four trees. “Pleasant to the sight” corresponds to the tsaddik who occupies himself with mitzvot and good deeds, which are like a beautiful garment for him and also in the view of his fellow man, like giving charity and guarding the covenant (guarding himself from lust). In the Pirkei Avot7 this is called tiferet l’osei’ha, or “good [also bringing splendor, bringing honor] for the one who acts in this way,” as is explained in its place. The tree that is “good to eat” means one whose outside appearance is not so beautiful, since he has no great need of strengthening himself in mitzvot and good deeds as he is very good in his essence. This is called (ibid.) tiferet lo min ha’adam, or “appreciated8 by his fellow man,” meaning that within him and in the form of his person he is good and beautiful. “The tree of knowledge” means one who is in a state of constant uncertainty as to the nature of the will of the blessed God, corresponding to all the eebayot, the “if you want [then say],” in the Gemara (either proposing alternate solutions or raising legal problems). “The tree of life” is true tshuvah (return to the way of the Torah), which heals that which came before.

Corresponding to these four trees are the four rivers that irrigate them. The river Pishon waters the tree that is good to eat, for pishon denotes greatness and expansion (PISHon—hitPASHtut or expansion), for whoever is great in his roots may allow himself to expand as much as he wants, for all he does will be the will of the blessed God. This is the river that “circles the whole land of Havilla where there is gold.” The river Gihon waters the tree that is pleasant to the sight, for “Gihon” signifies modesty, as in holech al gichon, or “moving on the belly,” that its movements are not recognized; in other words, a tsaddik on the surface. This river circles the land of Cush, and he is one who is not yet complete in the depths of his heart and needs to strengthen himself in mitzvot and good deeds in order to expunge the refuse from his soul.

The third river is Hidekkel, and it waters the tree of knowledge of good and evil.
