This is the matter of taking the bones of Yosef, for when Moshe had accepted that the deficiency14 really depended on himself, then he began to enter himself into the attribute of the fear of God. This is hinted at in the bones of Yosef, for the main attribute of Yosef haTsaddik was the fear of God, as explained in the verse (Amos, 5:6), “lest the house of Yosef overcome like a fire.” And this is “he whose fear of sin precedes his wisdom,” which is the attribute of Yosef haTsaddik.
“And they took their journey from Succot, and they encamped at Eitam, on the edge of the wilderness.” (Shemot, 13:20)

“Succot” means trust (for living in a temporary dwelling requires trust), and, “Eitam” represents vigorous strength.15 “And God went before them by day with a pillar of cloud … the pillar of cloud did not depart from them by day nor the pillar of fire by night.” The pillar of cloud teaches of the fear of God, and the pillar of fire teaches of trust. Sometimes we find in the heart of man great trust and awesome strength, called “day,” which requires him to enter into the attribute of the fear of God. At other times we find in the heart of man pronounced fear, called “night,” which necessitates that he increase and strengthen his trust in the blessed God. This is the meaning of “with a pillar of cloud by day and a pillar of fire by night.” This is the explanation of the Mishna in Pirke Avot (Ch. 3, Mishna 17), “If there is no wisdom, then there is no fear, and if there is no fear, then there is no wisdom.” Wisdom is really vigorous strength, for wisdom fortifies and strengthens the heart of the wise. Yet still, if there is no fear of the blessed God, and he does not understand that in but an instant the blessed God can take away from him this wisdom, which is strength, then his wisdom is considered as nothing, for he fancies that his strength can withstand even the blessed God. There is no nonsense greater than this.

“If there is no wisdom then there is no fear,” meaning one who has no trust in the blessed God, yet he is constantly in a state of fear even with no words of Torah, then his fear is not authentic but rather imaginary, for one who truly fears God has in his heart strength and trust in the blessed God. This is as it says once, “and the children of Israel went on the dry land through the sea,” while another time it says, “through the sea on the dry land.” “Sea” teaches of fear, meaning prayer, and “dry land” teaches of vigorous strength and trust. The principal strength is the Torah, the strength of Israel, and in this a man will know that his prayer is accepted, if he can make words of Torah out of his prayer. Likewise he will know that his Torah is the Torah of truth if a prayer and heartfelt cry accompanies the Torah in which he is engrossed, for both must be joined together as one.
“… and at night in a pillar of fire to give them light, so that they might go by day and by night.” (Shemot, 13:21)

It is written (Tehillim, 68:36), “Awesome is E-lohim from Your sanctuary, the God of Israel gives strength and awesome might to His people, blessed is E-lohim.” “Awesome is E-lohim,” for there is much reason to fear and tremble before Him. Yet still, at the place of the Holy Temple, where all fear goes forth to the world, of this it says, “Awesome is E-lohim from Your sanctuary.” From there He gives “strength and awesome might” to His people Israel. Because of this the verse ends, “blessed is E-lohim,” meaning that He has a fountainhead of life that is ever flowing and never ceasing. Yaakov Avinu had these two attributes of fear and trust, corresponding to the face of the eagle in the Merkava (chariot) of Yechezkel, for it is the nature of the eagle to be merciful with its own young and cruel to strangers. This is to “go by day,” meaning with mercy toward Israel, and “by night,” against the nations.
“… that they turn back and encamp before Pi Hahirot ….” (Shemot, 14:2)

On the matter of the impurity of this form of idolatry, which is the kelipah16 of z’nut, or rampant licentiousness, so accordingly this particular idol in the desert was in the form of a male and female.17 Therefore its name was Pi Hahirot,18 for the nations suppose that freedom means that they can extend themselves and perform all the desires of their heart. On this Pharaoh said, “they are confounded in the land,” meaning that when they reach this form of idolatry it will seem to them that they are enslaved (and confounded by this) since they make such efforts to fence themselves off from physical desire. Yet actually the opposite is true, for they the nations are enslaved to this, for since their own hearts are not in their possession (or in their control) such that their intellect should rule over them. Yet rather, their desires rule over them, and there is no enslavement greater than this.
“… over against it shall you encamp by the sea.” (Shemot, 14:2)

It is written (Gemara Berachot, 63a), “Know Him in all your ways, even concerning a sin.” Such is the case with “over against it [the idol of ba’al tsafon] shall you encamp by the sea.” Even if your actions are similar to the Egyptians, yet still, the actions of Israel are good, for the people of Israel, who are the portion of the blessed God, are cleaving in simple life without any garment of separation and drawing their energy from this the Source of life. Just as the blessed God is disencumbered of any attribute or any external appearance, but rather exists in absolute simplicity, so too is Israel at the source of its life free of any external force, separating garment, or subordinate power. Whether concerning wisdom, or elevated status, or wealth, it is (at the source) disencumbered of any influence other than God. With the nations, however, each particular nation has its own power and external coloring, from which it draws its life force and to which it grasps.

For example, the power of Babylon was in its status, and the power of the Philistines was in each one asked for a certain trick with which to attain wealth, or a known form of wisdom, or a craft where he could be sure to gain from it a livelihood. The matter of Moab and its kelipah was strength, for it was strong in its mind from the power of eating and similar things that strengthen and extend the mind. This was the form of its idolatry, called Chemosh (meaning “dried”), meaning the form of a man dried from its childhood form.19 This is what they feared in particular, lest this power that extended them would be taken away, like a man in his old age where his desire to eat decreases and he can no longer extend his mind as before. And similarly all the nations, each one in its own way.

Now the blessed God dispersed Israel among the nations, and this was so they would be among these powers, so that they could clarify, refine, and “whiten” themselves concerning these powers, and not turn to them, rather placing their trust in God. And in the future, when the blessed God will redeem them, then He will give them all the powers from which they had refined themselves, like the elevated status of Babylon, the good wealth of the Philistines, the mind extensions of Moab. He shall give them all of these in recompense for all the tribulations they incurred in exile. Thus when the blessed God shall plant these good things among Israel, then these attributes will be filled with Kedusha (holiness) and also among Israel they will be without limits, as they are coming from the blessed God. Among the nations of the world these good things are given in a certain amount with a limit, but with Israel they will be of the Providence of the blessed God, so of itself they will be without limit, for the blessed God is without limit.

This matter is explained in the prophecy of Yesahya concerning the fall of the Philistines where it is said, “and the firstborn of the poor I shall feed, and the needy shall lie down in safety, and I will kill your root with famine” (Yesahya, 14:30). These will be repayed measure for measure. Since they say that they need to run after reasons for livelihood, in order that they should have security in their lives (yet security based on a subordinate earthly power), therefore it is said, “and I have killed your root with famine.” Then when they fall, their power and bounty will be entered into Israel, since they were in exile among them and were tested concerning this attribute, and did not place their trust in it but rather in the blessed God. Therefore, “the firstborn of the poor I shall feed,” meaning Israel, who are poor and placing their reliance in the blessed God, so now with their (rich Philistines’) fall they (poor Israel) will be fed and supported.

In a similar way will it be with the downfall of all the other nations. This is the explanation of the verse, “over against it shall you encamp by the sea,” for enumerated here are four powers and kelipot of Egypt, which are migdol (tower), yam (sea), ba’al tsafon (master of the north), and pi haheirot (the mouth of freedom). Therefore the verse says, “over against it shall you encamp,” meaning corresponding to them and similar to them in their powers, so will all the benefits and bounty of Egypt be yours, and nevertheless you will be redeemed from them and they will fall before you. For all of these powers, when they are among Israel, are filled with Kedusha even if they seem similar to Egypt, for “E-lohim made them one over against the other [everything in Kedusha has its “evil twin” in impurity].” The accuser had seen them at the Red Sea and claimed, “what is the difference between these and these? [for they both served idols],” yet the blessed God testified for them that there is nothing in the hearts of Israel except the love of the blessed God.
“… and the children of Israel left with a high hand.” (Shemot, 14:8)
The Aramaic translation reads, “with an uncovered head,” meaning not with high hand against others, but rather with pride and confidence, since they are now free, without fear from any man.
“God will fight for you, and you shall be silent.” (Shemot, 14:14)

Concerning this they were commanded to hold their peace and refrain from action, not even to pray to the blessed God. With the war against Amalek we find the opposite, where it is said, “and it was, when Moshe lifted his hands [they succeeded],” and it said, “and his hands were emunah, steady [faithful],” where the Aramaic translation reads, “his hands were spread out in prayer.” There is a difference between Amalek and the rest of the nations. The rest of the nations say that not all is in the hands of Heaven, and ascribe all the influence of good on their own power, saying, “my strength and the power of my hands has gotten me this wealth.” Therefore in Israel’s war with Egypt they were commanded to hold their peace, meaning to show that all is in the hands of Heaven, and even the prayer that a man offers cannot be done independent of the will of the blessed God. Thus it is said, “and you will be silent.”

Yet with Amalek, called by the Gemara in Kedushin (18a), “the apostate of Israel,” he ascribes all his actions to the blessed God, saying that all the evil that he does comes from the will of the blessed God, for without the will of the blessed he could not do this. Against him the advice given is to show that the fear of Heaven is in the power (the choice) of man, and man needs Divine service and prayer. On this it says in the Gemara (Sanhedrin, 60a), concerning Ravshakei, an apostate of Israel (see 2 Kings, Ch. 18), who said, “have I come up to this place without God to destroy it?” In this way he attributes his evil actions to the blessed God, and against him the advice was given to pray.20
“Thus God saved Israel on that day ….” (Shemot, 14:30)

After the salvations of the redemption from Egypt they needed to experience tsimtsum (constriction). In the days of Passover there is a constriction with regard to eating, hinted at in matsah, “the bread of poverty,” but here (in this verse) after they merited the splitting of the Red Sea on the seventh day of Passover, it says, “thus God saved,” etc. On that day they no longer needed fences and restrictions, and this is hinted at in what is written in the Mishne Torah (meaning the book of Devarim, 16:8), “six days,” and it does not say seven.21
“… horse and its rider He threw into the sea.” (Shemot, 15:1)

“Horse” teaches of speed and expansion. “Rider” teaches of a settled frame of mind that contains the horse so it will not run. With the nations of the world, at a time when they see the pleasures of this world, they do not have the power to contain themselves but rather expand with all the desires of their hearts. Therefore it says concerning them, first “horse” and after “rider,” for after they have been filled with all their desires they do not have the power for more, and they cease to act. Yet with the blessed God it says (Habakuk, 3:8), “when You ride upon Your horses and chariots of salvations.” For it says first “You ride,” meaning that when the blessed God gives good to Israel, before it comes into the possession of man, He constricts it, so that he does not take until he fears the giver. Then He gives it in a way that it will be received in the full will of the heart. This is why it says first “when You ride,” teaching of reckoning and a settled mind, and after “Your horses,” denoting the effluence of good with great velocity.
“God is a man of war, God is His name.” (Shemot, 15:3)

It is written in the Midrash on the Scroll of Esther (Rabba, 6:3), “With evil ones, their personal name precedes, ‘is their name,’ such as ‘Naval is his name,’ ‘Sheva ben Bichri is his name,’ and so forth. Yet with the tsaddikim, ‘their name is’ precedes their personal name, such as ‘his name is Menoach,’ ‘his name is Kish,’ ‘his name is Mordechai.’ This is because they resemble their Creator, of whom it was said, ‘and My name YHVH I did not make known to them’ (Shemot, 6:3).” Concerning how it is said here, at the song at the sea, “God is His name,” for we find that with tsaddikim, “the name” precedes their personal name, because they control their hearts, their hearts are in their possession. The expression “his name” teaches of will, for even shmo, “his name,” is numerically equivalent to “ratson,” “will” (both equal 346) as is mentioned in the Midrash (Bereshit Rabba, 34:11). The tsaddikim control their wills in a way that what comes into their minds, they will consider, and if they deem it improper they will not do it. With evil ones it is the opposite, for they are the possession of their hearts.

As it is written in the Midrash (Yalkut B’shalach 241 in the name of the Midrash Avchir), “the angel of Egypt came to recommend that the blessed God be merciful with them, so the angel Gavriel came with a brick, placed it before the Holy One, blessed be He, and said, ‘with this Egypt has subjected Israel to slave labor.’ ” So with all of Egypt’s sins and wickedness, there was still a little room to teach of their merits, for their hearts also had a small inclination toward good. Therefore it is proper for the blessed God to be merciful with them and see to their welfare (the argument of the angel of Egypt). But when Gavriel came and showed them the brick,22 meaning that if they enslaved Israel with such a level of wickedness then there could not be any tendency to good in their hearts whatsoever. Therefore the blessed God said, “God is His name,” meaning that He will deal with them measure for measure, for just as they had no control over their hearts, so too God will not change His will from the attribute of stern justice, and this is “God is His name.”
“Who is like You among the powers [eileem] Hashem? Who is like You, glorious [ne’edar] in holiness ….” (Shemot, 15:11)

“Who is like You among the powers,” meaning that in His blessed essence He is hidden from the eye of all life, and no one can apprehend Him, as it is explained in the Gemara (Gittin, 56b), “who is like You among the speechless.”23 “Glorious in holiness,” meaning openly revealed, for in everything it is greatly recognized that it has a Creator, for all created beings will show evidence that there is a Creator, for on every thing encountered it comes to the heart of all who seek God to ask, “who created these?” This is the meaning of the phrase in the liturgical poem, “ha’ederet ve’ha’emuna,” “the glory and the faith, to the Life of all worlds [God].” “Glorious” means revealed and “faith” means hidden and concealed. Something that is not hidden needs no faith, only something that is concealed requires faith, and this is because in the view of man all that is openly revealed is that a great wonder created all of these. These two aspects, meaning the hidden and the revealed, are united only in the blessed God.
“And Moshe had Israel travel from the Red Sea ….” (Shemot, 15:22)

When Moshe Rabeynu saw that Miriam the Prophetess had sung the song, then he knew that it was time to move on from their place. Thus it is with the blessed God at a time when He effuses a renewal of the words of Torah to Israel, first He effuses to the hearts of the leaders and tsaddikim among them. Then afterward the matter extends until it reaches the hearts of all of Israel, until the smallest of the small, until this holiness (from now on, Kedusha) comes to the hearts of the women. Then the renewal is completed, meaning that it has been installed in the hearts of Israel, and then it is necessary for a new renewal of the words of Torah. Thus it was with the song at the sea, first in the mouth of Moshe, and then in the mouths of all Israel, and when it was said, “and Miriam sang for them,” then it followed immediately, “and Moshe had Israel travel.” Meaning that from now on you need not occupy yourselves with this matter, for you have already finished what was needed, and now we need to renew the words of Torah.24
“… and they went three days into the desert and did not find water.” (Shemot, 15:22)

After the great event they experienced at the Red Sea, and the great understanding received with the revelation of the Shechina (Divine Presence) as is explained (Mechilta B’Shalach, 3), “a maidservant saw at the splitting of the Red Sea more than the prophets,” then they went on for three days without having effused to them any renewal of Torah. This is the meaning of “they did not find water,” that they did not find the longing and the desire [for Torah], and their spirits fell greatly from this. What follows is “and God showed them a branch,” which the Aramaic translation renders “He taught them advice.” The advice was that even this absence of the renewal of Torah (this “dry period”) is also filled with light and goodness from the blessed God since this is His blessed will, so it is also goodness of great depth.

In this it say in the Midrash (Tanchuma, B’Shalach, 24), “He made sweet the bitter,” and with this intention he gave them there at (the place they named) “Mara” (bitter) the laws of Shabbat, the Red Heifer, and the Justice System. “Shabbat” means that they saw the blessed God gave them a way to serve Him even with the absence of action, so there is no reason to complain. “Red Heifer” teaches of the future, for in the future, “He will be one and His name one,” and then the service will be discontinued and there will be no anger. “The Justice System” teaches of order, for then they will not think to press the hour in order to merit all this goodness, for this must all be in an order so it can be fixed in the heart without any change.

“And He said, if you will surely hearken to the voice of Hashem your God, and do what is Honest in His sight, and diligently adhere to His voice, and guard His laws, then I will not put on you any of the diseases I put upon Egypt, for I am God, who heals you.” (Shemot, 15:26)

It is written in the Holy Zohar (Parshat B’Shalach Shemot, 60b), “If you will surely hearken,’ this is the ‘Knesset Yisrael,’ the community of all Israel [the Shechina]. ‘And do what is honest in His eyes,’ this is tsaddik [the righteous]. ‘And diligently adhere to His voice,’ this is, ‘Netsach,’ the sefira of eternity or victory. ‘And guard His laws,’ this is, ‘Hod,’ the sefirah of majesty or splendor.” [A little further the Zohar continues,] “corresponding these four there is a safeguarding for the holy, ‘roshem,’ residue or aftereffect. Safeguarding Knesset Yisrael is done by keeping the laws of nidda, family purity. Safeguarding of the tsaddik is done by keeping guard from the ‘maidservant’ (adulterous relations). Safeguarding of Netsach is done by keeping guard from the daughter of the Gentile. Safeguarding of Hod is keeping guard against the harlot.” The explanation: “Keeping guard from the daughter of the Gentile” means from that which has no portion at all in Israel. “The Harlot” is that which has a portion in Israel but it belongs to another and not to you. “Nidda” means that it belongs to you but its time has not yet come. “The Maidservant” means nonsense and things that are unnecessary, and (refraining from this) guards the tsaddik.25
“And He said, if you will surely hearken to the voice of Hashem your God.” (Shemot, 15:26)

Meaning that you will be willing to hear His voice, and this is the fulfillment of the mitzvot. “And that which is honest in His eyes you will do”—“honest” means that you will do His commandments with love and affection, and you will understand to have in mind the awesome depth of His blessed consciousness to do more than He has commanded you. Thus the honesty of your heart has instructed you, for that is honest in the eyes of the blessed God. For example, to go beyond what is required to adorn the mitzvah up to a third more than was commanded. “And diligently adhere to His voice, and keep all His laws” teaches of alacrity, to fulfill them immediately, and “laws” [choq] teaches of that which exceeds the capacity of the intellect, and then “for I am God who heals you,” and you will be healed from all.
“And they did not listen to Moshe, and some of them left it [the manna] until morning, and it bred worms, and became repulsive.”(Shemot, 16:20)

The matter that the manna “bred worms and became repulsive” teaches that they had unwarranted and repulsive humility, for even though they knew that the blessed God would not abandon them, yet still they worried that manna would descend to all of Israel but not to them. This is repulsive humility, for no one should see himself as worse than all the rest of Israel.
“And Amalek came and made war with Israel in Rephidim.” (Shemot, 17:8)

The matter of the sin at Rephidim was that they desired an elevated status, yet at that time it was not possible to come to any elevated status against Moshe, for “of what use is a candle against the bright sky?” [Hullin, 60b] This was the situation with the quarrel Israel where it is said “that they tested God saying, is God among us?” and the result of this sin was the war with Amalek, for Amalek senses whenever Israel misses the target even to a hair’s breadth. This is why Yitro came at this time (to fix this), as it say in the Midrash (Shemot Rabba, 27:3), “Smite a scorner, and the simple will become prudent. ‘The simple will become prudent,’ this is Yitro,”26 for he gave the advice that even in the time of Moshe Rabeynu to give elevation in status, in saying “to make princes over thousands,” etc. Then the great among them will be raised over the small, until Moshe Rabeynu.

chapter.title: PARSHAT YITRO
chapter.p: “And Moshe heard the voice of his father in law [Yitro] and did all that he had said.” (Shemot, 18:24)

At the end of the verse “he had said,”27 is vocalized with the vowel kamats, under the mem as opposed to the usual patach. This is also to signify that Yitro also did not know the great depths of his own words, how far he had intended, only Moshe understood his words. This is, “as he said [amar],” vocalized with a kamatz, for Yitro also said things to himself, and he himself did not understand the values of their preciousness.28
“And now, if you will surely hearken to My voice, and you will keep My covenant, then you shall be My most beloved treasure [segula] ….” (Shemot, 19:5)

Segula means a treasury and vessel of reception for all the hidden things of the kings. Thus the blessed God said to Israel that He would make them into a vessel of reception in order to place in them all the goodness and blessings that He has, and that they could receive them. In this way did the Holy Yehudi of Pshiske29 explain this same verse, that the love of the blessed God for Israel was in the way of segula, a beloved treasure, meaning without any discernible reason.30
“… for all the earth is Mine.” (Shemot, 19:5)

According to the context it should have been said, “for all the peoples of the world are Mine.”31 However, after the blessed God had chosen Israel to be His portion, and basically ended His dealings with the nations of the world (in terms of individual Providence), He took from them the power of free choice. Then it was inconceivable to call them by a specific name, and rather included them in the category of the earth.
“… and the voice of exceedingly loud shofar … Moshe spoke, and God answered him in a voice.” (Shemot, 19:16–19)

It is explained in the tractate Berachot (45a), “from here we derive that the translator will not raise his voice louder than the one reading the verse from the Torah.”32 “God answered him in a voice,” was like the translator reading after him at the same volume. This would seem quite unusual, and the sages of the Tosafot and R. Itschak Alfasi (the “Rif”) proposed that the opposite would seem to be understood from the verse.33 While Moshe indeed spoke the Ten Commandments to Israel, the root of the matter was that the words of Torah were then fixed into the hearts of Israel. This was done by the blessed God, who imprinted into the heart of each one according to His blessed will. In this way the blessed God is called, as it were, the translator, meaning that after the Ten Commandments went forth from the mouth of Moshe to Israel, the Holy One, blessed be He, went back and imprinted them into their hearts. This is “the translator will not raise his voice more than the reader,” for truly it was in the power of the Holy One, blessed be He, to carve the words of Torah into their hearts according to His blessed power, much more than Moshe Rabeynu could. However, it is written, “no more would a prophet as great as Moshe arise in Israel,” and it is that He not illuminate into any soul in Israel more than he did with Moshe Rabeynu (and would never again). So this is the meaning of “the translator will not raise his voice more than the reader,” meaning more than the level of Moshe Rabeynu.34
“Anochi Hashem E-loheicha—I am Hashem your God ….” (Shemot, 20:2)

The word Ani is not used for “I” (but rather, Anochi). Had it been written “Ani,” the meaning would have been that the Holy One, blessed be He, had revealed His light to Israel in all its completeness, and then they could not have reached deeply into His words, for He would have already revealed everything. However the additional letter Caf in “Anochi,” teaches that it is not in a state of completeness, yet rather an imagined image of the light that the Holy One, blessed be He, would reveal in the future.35 The more a man apprehends in the depths of the Torah, the more he will then understand that until now he was in darkness. This is hinted at in the night and the day. “Day” means that the blessed God opens the gates of wisdom for man, and “night” means that man should not imagine that he has apprehended all in completeness, for all he has attained is like night in comparison to the day that follows. So it goes on forever, and it follows that all is night in the face of the light that the Holy One, blessed be He, will open in the future.

This is why the verse that follows immediately is, “do not make any graven [carved] image,” on which it is said in the Holy Zohar (Shemot, 87b), “since it was first written, ‘carve for yourself [two tablets],’ therefore it says, ‘do not make any carved image,’ meaning do not make another torah.” The word pesel, “carved image,” means something with definite form and measurement, in a state of completeness with nothing lacking, and this only exists in the Torah of Moshe Rabeynu. However for the mortal intellect to fashion something in complete perfection like this is impossible.

On this it is written (Ruth Rabba, 3:2), “Caesar said to Rabi Yehoshua ben Hanina, ‘I too can make a Torah like Moshe,’ and he decreed that no fire be kindled for three days. During this time he saw smoke rising from a house, and they explained to Caesar that a certain government minister was sick and it was necessary to permit him fire.” For indeed, according to our Holy Torah the law is that saving a life supersedes the laws of Shabbat, yet the difference (with us and the example of Caesar) is that one who violates Shabbat to save a life is not going against the Holy Torah, for thus was it also commanded that saving a life takes precedence over the laws of Shabbat. So, too, in all places where it is, “a time to do for God,” (Tehillim, 119:126) in that very place is also hinted, “for they have made void Your law.”36 Therefore the Torah includes all the possible combinations of events that may occur, and its light surrounds all the possibilities and all the experiences that may evolve, and this is not in the power of any man to do this. This is the explanation of the Holy Zohar on “do not make any carved form,” meaning positive commandments, and “any image,” the prohibitive commandments, for nothing is revealed to man until it reaches its completion.
“I am Hashem your God ….” (Shemot, 20:2)

It is written in the Holy Zohar, “and the tree of life is in the secret of five, five,” and this is also the matter here. “Anochi, I,” is the source of life. “Hashem” is Gevurah—strength, which brings all into being. “E-loheicha, Your God” means the measure of truth in which the blessed God runs His world. “Who brought you out of the land of Egypt” means that even at a time when you experience anguish, God forbid, still refrain from becoming angry at the blessed God. “From the house of bondage” means do not become immersed in niceties, and after this is warned not to imagine that these things that I have told you can easily be done, yet rather they require great efforts of purification. Each of these five corresponds to one of the next five. “You shall not have” corresponds to “Anochi,” so as not to think that there is a hue (surface appearance) of life, God forbid, aside from Him.37 “Other gods,” meaning a hue of Gevurah—strength.38 “Before Me” corresponds to “your God,” meaning a hue of truth that is only superficial, and not part of truth at its deepest level.39 “Do not make any sculpted idol or image” corresponds to “who brought you out of the land of Egypt.”40 “From the house of bondage” corresponds to “which is in the heavens above,” etc.

The heavens, earth, and the seas are the principal forms in the construction of the world, and the world also contains desire and honor. Jealousy is also included in these two, as it is for these that He is jealous, and they are also the five corresponding to five mentioned above. “Do not bow down to them” means do not be subdued under them (desire and honor). “Do not serve them” means do not desire to rule over them. Existence is divided into three levels—place, time, and soul. Everything discussed thus far has been in the category of place. Corresponding to time, there is also the secret of “five, five.” Pesach is “Anochi—I.”41 Shevuot is “Hashem.”42 Succot corresponds to “Elo-heicha, your God.”43 Rosh HaShanah and Yom Kippur correspond to “E-l Kana, a jealous God,” for the name “E-l” teaches of Chochma (wisdom) and “jealous,” meaning anger, that is to say that His anger is in (the sefirah of) Chochma. In the category of soul, meaning person, there is also the secret of five, namely, “the fathers, the children, the third, the fourth [generations], and the thousandth [generation]” (Shemot, 20:5). Thus, all in the secret of “five, five,” and understand it, for it is a deep matter.
“I am Hashem your God ….” (Shemot, 20:2)

There are five faculties in human existence; imagination, thought, will, action, and speech. If the action (the effect in the world) is a result of these stages, beginning in the imagination,44 descending afterward to thought, and then to will, then he may be sure that this action came from the will of the blessed God, having flowed from the source of life. However, if the action came about by a different order, where first the will came to the heart, afterward descending to thought, then this action is in need of refinement, for perhaps the initial sprouting of this will was tainted by worldly desires. Corresponding to these five faculties were given the Ten Commandments, in order to refine these five stages.

For the Ten Commandments are also divided into five against five—five positive commandments in opposition to five prohibitions. “Anochi—I am Hashem” corresponds to the imagination (subconscious urge), for as long as the matter is in the state of the subconscious, it is not yet in the form of clear knowledge. This is like one who has the vague desire to do something yet does not yet know what it is, or the way small children, not yet possessing honed intellects, experience urges. It is also as when one sleeps, when his imagination is active on the level of the subconscious, yet without any recognition or discursive apprehension.

All of this corresponds to the first commandment, “Anochi,” in the realm of positive commandments, for the Divine utterance “Anochi” includes within it all the positive commandments of the Torah, with the will of God dwelling within them. With the prohibitive commandments, where all are in order “to turn from evil,” a man may apprehend them in his intellect, yet with positive commandments, which are the very locality of the blessed God, it is not conceivable that man may have any understanding of them. After that it is said, “you shall not have any other gods,” meaning that you are not to think that there is another Source of Being45 in the world, God forbid, besides Me, and this corresponds to the faculty of thought. “Do not take God’s name in vain” means not to discard anything in the world as unnecessary or useless.

Everything that the blessed God created has a spark of Kedusha (holiness) within it, only it has an internal and an external nature, and you need to know how to separate the good from the bad. This verse also corresponds to thought, for there are two verses, one corresponding to a positive commandment of thought, and another corresponding to a prohibition of thought. “Remember the Shabbat” and “Honor your father” correspond to the faculty of action. “Do not kill” and “do not commit adultery” correspond to will. The reason the commandments signifying action precede the commandments signifying will is that if one sins with an action, God forbid, he will go back and ponder it, and find some thought to hold responsible for it, meaning in the very source of his life. So then he must “do tshuva” [return to the way of God] in this regard, sincerely mending his ways and healing his roots, and not to find fault in the will, for the will could have been entered into him from the outside. “Do not steal” and “do not bear false witness” correspond to speech. This is because the entire need for speech is only in order to communicate with others, as the individual by himself has no need of speech. The Torah exists in all the worlds, so above this world “do not steal” means not to prevent words of Torah from reaching one’s students (Sanhedrin, 91b). This applies even to angels, as it is said of them, “and they receive one from the other.”46

For there are also different levels among the angels, and an angel on a higher level will have greater strength that one on a lower level. Yet the one on the lower level has a greater sense of fear (reverence for the greater strength), therefore “they receive one from the other.” “Do not bear false witness” is the opposite of “do not steal,” for it is to speak too much; and therefore these two correspond to the positive and negative commandments of the faculty of speech. “Do not covet” corresponds the prohibition in the faculty of the subconscious imagination, and belongs with “Anochi”; yet if one could achieve perfect refinement in the faculty of the subconscious, he would have no need of refinement in the other faculties. Therefore the prohibition in the faculty of the subconscious could not be written together with “Anochi,” but rather only after thought, will, action, and speech have been refined, then the subconscious imagination would emerge refined; so therefore it was written at the end.

The verse “Anochi—I am Hashem your God” contains all the letters of the Hebrew alphabet except Gimel”Zayin (“GeZ”), Chet”Tet (“CheT”), and Samech”Peh”Koof (“SaPheK”). “GeZ” teaches of the beginning of one’s acceptance of the yoke of the kingdom of Heaven, such as the convert who, when he comes to observance, must first limit his enjoyment of worldly pleasures and take great care of the details enumerated by the codifiers of the Law. This is “GeZ,” from the word geziza, or shearing away.47 Afterward comes CheT, which means sin, as he must guard himself to keep the mitzvot without sinning. Following this is SaPheK, meaning uncertainty, which means that he must fear what may be hidden in his heart.48
“Remember the day of Shabbat and sanctify it … and the seventh day is Shabbat unto Hashem your God.” (Shemot, 20:8–10)

Concerning why it says “Shabbat,” here twice, for all of the 613 commandments are called “Shabbat,” as it says in the Holy Zohar (Shemot, 88b), “What is Shabbat? A name of the Holy One, blessed be He.” This represents the time when the desire comes to man to do the will of God, doing that which He commanded, and refraining from that which He commanded not to do. When he takes this to his heart, this is as it says, “remember the day of Shabbat [meaning all God has commanded us].” Afterward, when man forgets, and did an action while the will of the blessed God is hidden from him, it is said, “six days shall you work … and the seventh day,” etc. Thus, at time when he has become far from Shabbat, and, God forbid, forgets God, the day of Shabbat still comes again, and he returns, placing his heart on that which he has done. By means of this a great cry erupts from his heart, saying, “what have I done?” For a man cannot uphold the Torah unless he has failed in it (Gittin, 53a). Then the blessed God gives him advice, which are the offerings that make atonement, so this is why it says directly after, “honor your father and mother.” This means not to blame your own faults on the fact of your birth, deeming yourself clean and exempt from offering sacrifices that will atone for you. This is “honor your father and mother.”
“You shall not make with Me gods of silver or gods of gold … an altar of earth you shall make for Me … in any place that I mention My name I shall come to you and bless you.” (Shemot, 20:20)

“Gods of silver,” meaning an external hue of love and fervor more than is appropriate for your position, for there is no associate with the One in heaven, and the blessed God only shows his love for man when the truth is with him. “Gods of gold,” meaning an external hue of fear greater than is befitting your position. Only, “an altar of earth you shall make for Me.” Here, “earth” means simplicity, just as it exists in your heart. In the verse, “In any place that I mention My name,” the word “mention” comes from the term for clarification, birrur.49 In every place where I make it clear that the point of origin in your heart was for the sake of heaven, then I will immediately send you the blessing, “and bless you.”
“You shall not ascend by steps on My altar, in order not to uncover your nakedness on it.” (Shemot, 20:23)

All the hearts of Israel are called “My altar,” and this is “do not ascend,” meaning not to boast in your own soul over any soul of Israel. This is as it says, “in order not to uncover your nakedness,” meaning so as not to come to shame by means of this, for if you pride yourself over anyone else, in the end you will descend below and he will go up into your place. This it says in the Gemara (Megillah, 16b), “of Mordechai who was first numbered fifth, and later sixth.”50

chapter.title: PARSHAT MISHPATIM
chapter.p: “And these are the laws that you shall place before them ….” (Shemot, 21:1)

Here it is not said, “And God spoke to Moshe saying,” as with all the commandments, for the matter here discusses civil legal enactments (“mishpatim”), and concerning justice there is no difference between the great and the small. This may be compared to when the king goes out to inspect and judge his soldiers; then they all stand in the same line, even their senior officer standing in the line. Thus it is written (Yesahya, 56:1), “keep justice, and perform tsedaka [righteousness], for My salvation is close at hand.” “Keep” is an expression of restraint, saying that no soul of Israel should voice angry complaints against the blessed God concerning His attributes (where He is concealed from us). He should refrain from asking why He does not help him to serve Him, especially as this is what He desires, so why does the blessed God not help him immediately?

Therefore it is said, “keep justice and perform tsedaka,” meaning to cleave to the blessed God with righteousness and honesty of heart, without angry complaints. This being done, “My salvation is close at hand,” meaning that the blessed God will reveal to us the order with which he conducts our lives in the exile. Then He will send consolation, making it clear that none of the longing and suffering that Israel underwent in the service of the blessed God was in vain. On this it is said in the holy Zohar (Shemot, 150b), “even a man’s good intention will not be lost,” for with every action man does, even if it seems now to be insignificant, in the future the blessed God will expand upon it greatly.

In this week’s Parsha, the blessed God teaches us how one must clean and refine himself, to the extent that his attribute of goodness is even drawn into his possessions, and then good attributes will be found in them so as not to cause damage to anyone else. Therefore, when a man’s possessions cause damage, he must pay for the damages, for the damage was done because his soul was not refined enough. Thus his possessions could cause damage, or he could steal from another, for if his soul was in a state of true refinement then his possessions could never do damage to another.

So it was told in the Gemara (Ta’anit, 25a), “the neighbors of R. Channina ben Dosa complained that his goat was causing them damages. He said, ‘if it is so, then let them be eaten by bears.’ The goats went into the forest, and returned each with a bear on its horns.” Furthermore, it is said in Berachot (16b), “Manservant and maidservants are not addressed as ‘father so-and-so’ or ‘mother so-and-so’ [a title of honor] except for the servants of the house of Rabban Gamliel, who were called so because of their importance.” This means that the power of the Kedusha of Rabban Gamliel extended even to his possessions, and they too were good (his goodness extended into them).
“… that you shall place before them ….” (Shemot, 21:1)

Rashi explains, “before them [Israel] and not before the idolaters, and even if you know that one of their judgments is the same as the judgments of Israel, do not bring it into their courts. One who brings the judgments of Israel before the heathens profanes the name of God, and gives honor to idolatry to praise it, as it is written [Devarim, 32:31], ‘for their Rock is not our Rock, even our enemies themselves being judges.’ This means, when our enemies are judges it is testimony to the superiority of their idol.” The matter is thus: Every man is cut from the same material, and the form of the limbs and organs is the same for everyone, yet however, the form of the Israelite is recognized and refined among all the nations. This matter defies logic, for if a thousand Gentiles stand with one Israelite among them, the form of the Israelite will be recognized, and this is a wonder in the eyes of all the whole world. This is because, “their Rock is not like our Rock,” even though with the Israelites, all their organs and the forms of their faces are exactly the same as the rest of the world, yet still, all who see them will recognize that this is the seed that God has blessed. “And our enemies themselves being judges” means that it is exactly the same in the realm of justice, for even if their judgments are exactly like those of Israel, nonetheless, if an Israelite goes to their courts he is profaning the name of God, for it has no likeness to the justice of Israel at the depths. On this it is written in the Tehillim (147:19), “He speaks His word to Yaakov, His statutes and judgments to Israel. He does not do this with any nation, and as for His judgments, they have not known them.”

“And [if a man] did not lie in wait [he did not lie in ambush for him, but killed him unintentionally. Rashi] but E-lohim caused it to come to be, then I will appoint you a place to where he may flee.” (Shemot, 21:13)

Rashi explains, “Concerning what does the Torah speak? Of two men, one killed inadvertently, and the other killed intentionally, and there were no witnesses to testify concerning the affair. Therefore the latter was not put to death, and the former was not exiled. The Holy One, blessed be He, brings them to the same inn, and the one who killed intentionally sits under a ladder; while the one who killed inadvertently ascends the ladder, falls, and kills the one who killed intentionally. Witnesses testify to this, and [the court] requires him to be exiled. So in the end, the one who killed inadvertently was exiled, and the one who killed intentionally was killed.” The famous question is, how did the one who inadvertently killed first come to do this? It seems that it may be explained through the verse (Tehillim, 145:14), “God supports all those who fall, and straightens all those who are bent down.” Two things are mentioned in this verse—fallen, and bent down.

This means, with one who has anger and evil lusts rooted in his heart, if God forbid he brings his potential into action, it is called “fallen.” If it still has not been brought forth into action, he is called “bent down,” meaning that his heart is bent and enslaved to this evil lust. The blessed God is the One whose thoughts are to never banish anything completely. Therefore it says, “but E-lohim caused it to be,” for with the one who killed inadvertently, it is not to say that he has already actually killed; rather that he has a deficiency in his heart, namely anger and desire to murder. With the one who killed intentionally, it means that he has already brought it into action and committed murder.

So the Holy One, blessed be He, completes both of them. The one who killed intentionally is killed, and the one who killed inadvertently is exiled. This is, “but E-lohim caused it to be,” meaning that the Holy One, blessed be He, did it for his benefit. All the while that the evil thought had not come into action it would not occur to his heart to repent. Yet now that the Holy One, blessed be He, has brought it about that he actually has killed someone inadvertently, and the one who was killed had anyhow deserved the death penalty, he began to become greatly agitated in his soul, asking himself, “why did it come about that I killed inadvertently? Certainly I must have a root of murder in my heart.” (Questions that he would otherwise not have asked.) By means of this he repents.
“Six days shall you do your work, and on the seventh day you shall rest ….” (Shemot, 23:12)

In Parshat Yitro, when the Shabbat is discussed, the opposite order is written; “remember the day of Shabbat to keep it holy,” and then afterward, “six days shall you work,” etc. This may be understood through what is written in the Gemara (Shabbat, 69b), “if one is wandering in the desert, and does not know when the day of Shabbat is, Hiya bar Rav says, he shall keep one day of Shabbat, and then count six. Rav Huna says, he shall first count six days, and then keep one day of Shabbat.”

In order to understand these two different approaches, consider the verse (Mishlei, 4:8), “Laud her, and she shall exult you, she shall honor you when you embrace her.” This means, laud something if it strengthens the desires of your heart and your involvement in the words of Torah. For instance, if you have a strong desire to eat and drink and the like, examine it and if, God forbid, it causes you to go against the will of God then refrain from it.

Then through this very examination, “and she shall exult you,” then the very words of Torah will raise you over all your lusts. “Honor her when you embrace her,” for “when you embrace her” means that if you increase how much you take counsel in the words of Torah each time more; then also, “she shall honor you” greatly in the eyes of all around you. Shabbat represents the acceptance of the yoke of the Torah, and a young Torah scholar who has not yet completed the purification of his heart is called “Hiya bar Rav,” who said to keep one day of Shabbat first. This means that one whose heart is not yet purified should not pray that the blessed God give him anything of the good in this world (“counting six days”), but should rather deliver over all his desires to Him (“starting with Shabbat”), and the blessed God will be the one who begins and finishes. “Rav Huna” represents an elder Torah scholar, for the name “Huna” is related to “Hon” or wealth; that is to say, he has found wealth in a large following of students, and his heart has been purified, containing no foreign desires.

Therefore it says that he shall first count six days, meaning that it is permitted for him to ask the blessed God to fulfill all the wishes of his heart, for the six days teach of the power of the actions of man. “Then keep one day of Shabbat” means that the blessed God will then complete matters for him, in the sense of (Iyov, 22:28), “you shall decree the matter, and it will be established for you.”
“You shall bring the first of the first fruits of your land to the house of Hashem your God; you shall not cook a kid in its mother’s milk.” (Shemot, 23:19)

This commandment teaches of the attribute of restraint, which is called in the Midrash, “valiant ones of power that can hold back their lust,” and it is written (Yeshiyahu, 28:4), “like an early fruit before summer, that as soon one sees it, it is yet swallowed up in his hand.” The Torah teaches to have restraint and not to eat it, but rather to bring it to the Cohen. “You shall not cook a kid in its mother’s milk” teaches of the opposite of this, of doing something quickly, as it is written in the Gemara (Succa, 14b), “[a succa with a hole in its wall large enough] for a kid to leap into it at once.” The Torah teaches that in a place that requires alacrity, do not hold back. This is, “do not cook,” meaning do nothing to prevent it being done quickly. “Milk” teaches of restraint, for something done with restraint is called constant, for it is always good to act in this way; yet sometimes a man needs to act quickly, as explained on the verse, “a horse ready for the day of war.”51 Then this attribute is much more praiseworthy than the attribute of a settled mind, which is called “constant.” Thus the attribute of quickness of action is called mekudash, “sanctified.” The Gemara discusses this, asking (Zevachim, 90b), “constant or sanctified, which is preferable?” and we find in the Gemara of Berachot (20a) “the Rishonim [early sages] gave over their lives for the sanctification of God’s name,” etc. This means that they acted with the attribute of quickness of action, a highly precious quality in its time. Thus a man must leave the realm of restraint, and because of this attribute (quickness) a miracle will be performed for him.
“And you shall serve Hashem your God, and He will bless your bread and water, and I will remove all sickness from among you.” (Shemot, 23:25)

This verse begins in the plural voice, and ends in the singular. This is understood according to what has already been explained in Parshat Vayeira on the verse, “and now I know that you fear E-lohim,” (page 25) concerning the difference between the fear of Hashem and the fear of E-lohim. The fear of E-lohim concerns a time when one must constrict himself in an area because of his own deficiency, as his heart is not yet refined. The fear of Hashem teaches that one must limit himself because of the entire community of Israel, even though he himself does not have a deficiency in this area.

Therefore, “and you shall serve” is voiced in the plural, for you must suffer constriction for the sake of the entire community of Israel. By means of this, “and He will bless your bread and water,” each one in particular. This is what we mean when we say the blessing, “baruch she’amar,” in the morning service, “blessed is He who has mercy on the land,” for the “land” hints at the entire community of Israel,52 as the blessed God first has compassion for the entire community. Only after (as the order in “baruch she’amar” continues), “Blessed is He who has compassion on His creation,” meaning each one of Israel in particular.
“And God said to Moshe, ascend to Me, to the mountain and I will be there ….” (Shemot, 24:12)

“To the mountain” means to the end of the renewal of all levels. A man must first pass through all of the forms of wisdom in the world until he reaches true wisdom. “And I will be there,” teaches of a place of purity and true life, as in (Bamidbar, 21:17), “and they went from there to the well.” (The well always represents the source of true wisdom.) This shows that all of the forms of wisdom were only stations on the journey, while the main point of your place is the end of all the levels, called there.”

chapter.title: PARSHAT TRUMA
chapter.p: “And God spoke to Moshe saying, take for Me an offering [truma] ….” (Shemot, 25:2)

This is as it is written (Yesahya, 45:1), “Thus spoke God … who formed the land … He did not create a desolation for his creations to dwell in…” In Parshat Yitro, when Israel heard the Ten Commandments, it was easy for them to fulfill them since these mitzvot depend on the actions of man. Then after, the Parsha of Mishpatim (Judgments) was said to them, and taught that it was the will of the blessed God that His Kedusha (holiness) and service (of Him) would spread forth to such an extent that even a man’s possessions could not do anything against the Torah as explained above in Parshat Mishpatim (cf. “and these are the judgments”). From this, a great crying out burst from the hearts of Israel asking how it could be possible to reach such a level of refinement. Therefore the blessed God gave them the advice in this Parsha, “take for me an offering [truma], gold, and silver, and copper.”

On this it says in the holy Zohar (Shemot, 148a), that these elements correspond to the basic elements found in man, meaning that he should deliver all his elements and potentialities over to the blessed God, so that He may manage them according to His blessed will. Then of itself his possessions will also contain goodness and will not suffer or cause any damage. On this it is explained in the Zohar (Bamidbar, 125), “The verse, ‘Fortunate is the man who God does not ascribe to him sin, and has not the spirit of deception,’ (Tehillim, 32:2) means that the spirit of his life does not turn to any side,” but is directed only to the will of the blessed God. If a man asks how it is possible to refine his heart to such an extent, on this it is said, “He did not create a desolation for His creations to dwell in,” meaning that God does not want man’s heart to be distraught.

This is also the meaning of (Yesahya, 45:19), “I did not say to the seed of Yaakov, seek Me in vain,” so therefore the verse says, “for his creations to dwell in,” meaning that a man should have a settled mind.53 [And the verse in Yesahya continues], “I am God, speaking righteousness, proclaiming fairness [meisharim, also even, right], meaning that even though the blessed God desires that man be righteous and clean in all matters, upholding 613 commandments, still He is “proclaiming fairness,” meaning with honesty and a willingness of heart toward man. Thus He gives man advice as to how to fulfill all the mitzvot with ease.
“…. take for Me an offering [truma] ….” (Shemot, 25:2)

It is written in the Midrash Tanchuma (Truma, 1), “Rabbi Yannai said, it is permitted to eat the truma offering on the grave of an unlearned Cohen.”54 All the Kedusha of the truma offering is drawn into the world by way of the Cohanim who eat it in a state of Kedusha. If there were no Cohanim in the world, then the truma would not possess any Kedusha. Therefore, with regard to an unlearned Cohen55 the truma never had any Kedusha as far as he was concerned. This is the explanation of the Midrash (Ibid.), “take for Me an offering—means take to Me, to My name.” That is, the entire greatness of the Kedusha of truma is if it is separated for the sake of Heaven.
“… take for Me an offering [truma]….” (Shemot, 25:1)

We can understand this through what has been explained on the verse (Mishlei, 16:24), “The way of life for the intelligent is above.” This means that principle and foremost is for one to place his heart on the way of life above. That is to say, the life and sustenance that the blessed God gives to all men is above, like something placed on high.56 So it is with “take for Me an offering,” meaning that Israel should “take” the blessed God exulted57 and first in all matters. This is as it is written in the Gemara of Sanhedrin (102b), “What part of the bread is taken when the blessing hamotsi is recited? From the part that was first baked [the outer crust].”

Relate this to what is written in the Gemara of Berachot (35a). “One verse says, ‘the earth is Hashem’s and the fullness thereof,’ and another verse says, ‘the land was given to mankind.’ The first verse is before the blessing is recited, and the second verse is after the blessing was recited.” The whole matter of a blessing is for one to be conscious that he has a Master and from Him he receives all effluence of sustenance. If you have such a consciousness then you can say “Blessed art Thou,” in the real presence of the blessed God. On this it is said, “and the land was given to mankind.” This is also the question, “on which part of the bread do you say the blessing hamotsi,” meaning, where is the deep recognition in this loaf of bread that the blessed God is giving it so you can truly say on it, “Blessed art Thou?” And the answer is, “from the part that was baked first.” There are so many stages in the work of our human hands that goes into making the bread; the kneading, arranging, heating the oven, putting it equally in the oven. But the very place where it starts baking is not a result of the power of mankind. Then when one takes this into his heart, asking why it started baking at this particular place, he sees that it has only come about from the will of the blessed God. Thus over this particular part of the bread is it proper to recite the blessing.

chapter.title: PARSHAT TETSAVE
chapter.p: “And you will command the children of Israel … take unto yourself pure olive oil ….” (Shemot, 27:20)

“Unto yourself,” meaning to the Chochma (wisdom) inherent in every soul of Israel, and all the wisdom of Israel is called in the name of Moshe Rabeynu. To this the blessed God commanded that every one of Israel shall take to the wisdom inside of him some pure olive oil, meaning refined wisdom, and that is that he should not turn to any side that might be tainted. Doing this he will understand who God has chosen, and that is why the verse following immediately after is, “bring close Aharon and his sons.”
“And these are the garments that they shall make, a breastplate, and an ephod, and a robe ….” (Shemot, 28:4)

In these garments the blessed God shows Israel which soul He chooses, for the preciousness of the soul of Aharon haCohen is recognized and understood from the garments (made for him). The Tsits (“headplate”) hints that he is constantly cleaving to the blessed God as he is commanded always to wear it on his forehead. Engraved on the tsits were the words Kodesh LeHashem, “Holy unto God,” meaning that the words (Divrei haYamim 1, 28:9), “Know the God of your father and serve Him,” were constantly in the depth of his thought. The breastplate (Choshen) hinted that there was no hatred for any soul of Israel in his heart, for the tribes of Israel were engraved on his heart. The ephod, with which he would gird himself, hinted at his trust in the blessed God, which always supported him. The robe (Me’il) teaches of his great fear of God, for it was made entirely of t’chellet (sky blue), which hints at fear.58 Why were the pants and the tsits not mentioned when the garments are enumerated in verse 4? The pants were not mentioned for they were not considered a garment, only serving to cover his nakedness; in other words, to guard from the lusts of this world. The tsits was not mentioned, as it is explained in the Zohar (Bamidbar, 159), “The brilliance [metscha, also “forehead”] of God’s desire is revealed at the Mincha [afternoon] Prayer of Shabbat.”59 The tsits was given to Aharon haCohen since he had great fear, for all the tribe of Levi possessed great fear, as it is written (Malachi, 2:5), “I gave him fear,” and all the more so the high priest. Even his very name teaches of fear for “Aharon” is the numerical equivalent of 256, corresponding to the 256 (2 to the eighth power) wings of the angels called chayot hakedoshim, and wings teach of fear.60

Corresponding to this great fear he was given the tsits to vivify and delight his soul, for the tsits teaches of the love that the blessed God has for Israel. Then at the time when the blessed God reveals His great love, all the fears depart, and Israel experiences great empowerment.61 Therefore before the making of the robe (Me’il) was mentioned it was not possible to mention the making of the tsits, for the great profusion of empowerment could, God forbid, bring forth an irreverent spirit. Therefore after the making of the Me’il, which teaches of fear was mentioned, it was then possible to mention the making of the tsits, as in the words of the Holy Zohar, “at the time of Mincha of Shabbat,” which is after great fear, “the brilliance of His desire is revealed,” meaning great empowerment.

“And these are the garments which they shall make: a breastplate [Choshen], and an ephod, and a robe [Me’il], and a broidered coat [C’tonet Tashbets], and a mitre [Mitsnefet] and a girdle [Avnet] ….” (Shemot, 28:4)

Corresponding to the eight priestly garments, the members of the great assembly (in the Second Temple period) codified the eight expressions in the blessing preceding the morning recitation of Shema, “to understand and to discern, to hear, to learn, and to teach, to guard, and to do, and to uphold.” “To understand” corresponds to the girdle [Avnet], for the girdle comes to make atonement for the fancies of the heart (Arachin, 16a), so too, was it worn over the heart and its length was thirty-two cubits.62 “To discern” corresponds to the breastplate [Choshen], for a man must consider carefully in order to know the blessed God, for with Him there is no anger against the souls of Israel [the names of the twelve tribes were engraved on the Choshen], for, “His wrath is for a moment, yet a lifetime in His will [favor]” (Tehillim, 30:6). “To hear” corresponds to the robe (Me’il), meaning that a man must hear and lead his ear to his foundation and root. This is explained (in Shemot Rabba, 40:3) on the verse (in Job), “where were you when I founded the world?” meaning where was your portion in Adam haRishon (when he sinned). Then when a man contemplates his portion in this he will then come to an understanding of what he has already fixed, and what he has yet to repair. This is hinted at in the robe (Me’il), for the Holy Zohar mentions that the Me’il is the secret of reincarnations (coming back until all is fixed, all the mitzvot have been fulfilled).

“To learn” corresponds to the mitre (hat, Mitsnefet), for the Mitsnefet makes atonement for coarseness of spirit (Arachin, ibid.), meaning to receive the truth from one who spoke it. “To teach” corresponds to the tsits (headplate), for of the tsits it is said, “and it shall be on his forehead continually that they may be accepted,” meaning that one needs a good eye in order to teach his fellow man. “To guard” corresponds to the embroidered coat (C’tonet), for the C’tonet makes atonement for the spilling of blood (ibid.). It teaches man to guard himself and to see that because of him no damage is done to his fellow man. Then his peers will not be able to suspect him, and then be punished for suspecting him in vain. Then he too will be punished for causing his fellow man to be punished. “To do” teaches of reliance, and the point of reliance is the performance of mitzvot, such that a man can stand in prayer and support himself on them.

This is as it is written (Tehillim, 104:3), “who makes the clouds His chariot,” and clouds teaches of the performance of mitzvot.63 “To fulfill” corresponds to the priestly pants, whose purpose is to cover his genitalia. This is a place on which a man stands to suffer a loss, as it is written (Bereshit, 42:9), “the nakedness of the land,” meaning the vulnerable place by which the land may be conquered. At every place the blessed God created from which a man could build an everlasting structure, there He also created a place of vulnerability where he may lose all. However, by means of guarding himself here, then from this place an everlasting structure will emerge.

“And you shall set it [the Choshen Mishpat] with four rows of stones; a carnelian [or carneol, or saridus], a topaz, and a smaragd [or carbuncle, or emerald, or agate] shall be the first row of stones. And the second row shall be a carbuncle [also turquoise, ruby, emerald, garnet], a sapphire, and a diamond. And the third row shall be an opal [also ligure, jacinth], an agate, and an amethyst. And the fourth row shall be a beryl [also chrysolite, topaz], and an onyx, and a jasper …” (Shemot, 28:17).

Carnelian represents the tribe of Reuven, for its name in Hebrew, odem, is closely related to adom, red, the color of simcha. The name Reuven is derived from sight (see Bereshit, 29:32), for with all his dealings and words he always sees himself standing in the presence of God, and God then illuminates his eyes. This causes man to experience great joy, as it is written (Mishlei, 15:30), “the heart rejoices at the illumination of the eyes.”

Topaz represents the tribe of Shimon, for the tribe of Shimon possesses great depths in the words of Torah, yet before they can bring them forth into actuality the must undergo refinement. Therefore Rabbi Shimon bar Yochai (the famous figure in the Talmud and author of the Zohar), since he was from the tribe of Shimon, possessed a depth of understanding in the words of Torah on the level of Moshe Rabeynu. Topaz or Pitdah hints at this, for its first and last letters spell “mouth” and the remaining letters, Tet and Dalet, are the letters just before Yud and Hei in the Hebrew alphabet. Yud Hei teach of the depth of wisdom64 that is found in this tribe, yet it cannot bring it forward through speech.

Smaragd represents the tribe of Levi, for bareket hints at the fear of God, as it contains the letters of the word for lightning, barak, whose light is revealed suddenly, in a flash. In this the tribe of Levi possesses the refined fear of God, as it is written of them (Malachi, 2:5), “I gave them My covenant for the fear with which he feared me.”

“And the second row shall be a carbuncle….” Carbuncle corresponds to the tribe of Yehuda, for it vacillates between all the colors, as all the colors are contained within it. So it is with the tribe of Yehuda, which does not stay fixed in one attribute, but rather when Yehuda is among the perfectly righteous he is perfectly righteous, and when he is among the “ba’alei tshuva,” he is then the greatest penitent. This is as we find in the Gemara (Shabbat, 56a), “all who say, ‘David was a sinner,’ are mistaken,”65 and we also find (Moed Katan, 16b), “He raised an offering of tshuva.”66 Further proof of this is how at one time he says in the book of Tehillim (86:1–2), “I am poor and destitute,” and then right after he says, “I am a Hasid.”67

Sapphire—Sapir—corresponds to the tribe of Yissachar, for the sapphire teaches of clear and refined wisdom, as it says (Shemot, 24:10), “like the paved work of sapphire stone, and the essence of the heavens for clearness.” Of the tribe of Yissachar it is said, (Divrei haYamim 1, 12:32), “and the children of Yissachar were men of understanding for the times,” as they knew how to create leap years and fix the beginning of the months. This is a kind of knowledge that is possessed only by those to whom God has granted refined wisdom.68 This is hinted at in that the 1,080 seconds in an hour is the numerical equivalent of four times E-lohim.69

Diamond represents the tribe of Zevulun, for diamond, yahalom, is split up into the words, roughly translated, “God hither.” Zevulun was confidant that the blessed God was with him for all his endeavors, even though they seemed like worldly affairs, as it is said (Megillah, 6a), “Zevulun dealt in trade.” Even there (“hither”) he was deeply connected to God.

“And the third row shall be opal,” etc. “Opal” represents the tribe of Dan, for in this tribe we find God-given strength70 and great resolve for victory. The mortal eye sometimes mistakes these attributes for anger, and on this the Torah testifies that he is a vessel dedicated to God. This is found in the name of the place that he was given as an inheritance, as it says (Shoftim, 18:29), “however, the name of the city was at first Layish.” Layish is another word for lion, and teaches of God-given strength and bravery, “as it is written (Mishlei, 30:30), “the lion is mighty among the beasts, and will not return in the face of all adversity.” Yet after this city fell in their inheritance its name was changed to leshem, which teaches that all his power is due to his confidence that the blessed God will help him, and this is because he walks in simplicity.

This is as it is explained in the Gemara (Pesachim, 4a), “A certain man used to say, ‘Judge my case.’ They said, This proves that he is descended from the tribe of Dan, as it is written, ‘Dan shall judge his people, as one of the tribes of Israel.’” This is because he has God-given strength that surely he would be found innocent if judged, for with all the matters of this world, even with the mitzvot and good deeds that a man does, they remain in the balance even after the action is completed. For instance, if a man gives charity to a pauper, and the pauper later goes with this power and performs a mitzvah, then the one who gave the charity is assisting his performance of the mitzvah. If the pauper takes the money and uses it for a transgression, then the one who gave the charity is assisting him in transgressing. So the Godly vigor of the tribe of Dan in his confidence in God that because he did the mitzvah in simplicity then blessed God will not cause him to fail because of it. Certainly the blessed God brought him an honest pauper who took this power to do a mitzvah.

“Agate”—shevo—represents the tribe of Naftali, for shevo is related to the word for “return”—shav. This means that even when he goes to engage in matters of this world, and it seems to the mortal eye that, God forbid, his heart is not with God, then at that moment his heart returns and “gazes” on God. The name of the chief of the tribe of Naftali teaches of this, whose name was Achira ben Einan, for Achira contains the word for “back”—achor—meaning that he always takes the back way (engaging in the matters of this world) and does not look back. “Einan” however, is related to “eye”—ain—meaning that even in this his eyes are constantly looking toward the blessed God.

“Amethyst”—achlama—corresponds to the tribe of Gad, meaning gathering together, and great God-given strength at a time when it is necessary to gather all of Israel together according to the will of the blessed God. So from this tribe all kinds of Godly strengths go forth to Israel,71 as it is written of Gad (Bereshit, 49:19), “Gad, a troop shall troop upon him, but he shall troop upon their heel.”72

“And the fourth row shall be a beryl,” etc. “Beryl” corresponds to the tribe of Asher. Asher signifies expansion, spreading forth, and so too does beryl teach of expansion, as it is written (Daniel, 10:6), “His body was like beryl.”73 This tribe also experienced expansion, as it is written (Bereshit, 49:20), “out of Asher his bread shall be fat.”

“Onyx”—shoham—represents the tribe of Yosef. “Shoham” is love, as is explained in the verse (Bereshit, 2:12), “there was the Bedellium.”74 Yosef too had a fierce love for the blessed God, so much so that he could easily abandon all the pleasures of this world for the love of the blessed God. For out of the fear of God alone he could not withstand the temptation of the wife of Potiphar, as it is written in the Gemara (Nedarim, 32b), “At the time of the control of the inclination to evil, no one can remember the inclination to good.” This could only be done out of love for the blessed God, who at the moment of that trial showed him a vision of the visage of his father Yaakov, and how his very name would be engraved on the stones of the Ephod of the High Priest.

“Jasper”—yoshpeh—is for the tribe of Binyamin, meaning that he has a mouth75 [yesh peh in Hebrew] that can swallow and receive all the goodness that exists in the world. This is as it is written of him (Bereshit, 49:27), “Binyamin is a wolf that devours.” He even has the power to collect and receive the goodness that exists among the nations of the world, looking at the good among them and entering them into Israel.
“And you shall make an altar to burn the incense; make it of acacia wood.” (Shemot, 30:1)

All the vessels were mentioned in Parshat Truma except for the golden incense altar. This can be understood through what is written in the holy Zohar (Bamidbar, 151b), “what is incense? It is the connection of all.”76 This hints that all done, even in “this world,” is all connected in the will of the blessed God, and without His will nothing at all would be done. One who misunderstands this could come to irreverence, God forbid, since everything that happens is allowed to happen from Heaven. Therefore the incense altar, which represents this understanding, was not said in Parshat Truma, but only after the explanations of the priestly garments in this Parsha, which teach of the great fear of God and vigilant guarding from the vain pleasures of this world. As it is written in the Gemara (Arachin, 16a), “the ctonet, or tunic of chequer work, makes atonement for the spilling of blood,” and so it is with all of the garments. By means of his priestly garments, the Cohen sends great fear of God to the heart of each one in Israel. Then after the Cohen has instilled such fear in the heart of Israel, then they have the ability to receive the simcha and love that comes from the power of the incense.

All of the vessels of the Mishkan were made of acacia wood inlayed with gold, except for the caporet (the covering for the Holy Ark) and the menorah, where it is specified that they be made of pure gold, not filled with acacia wood. It is known that the Mishkan and its vessels hint at the upright form of man, and for each limb man has the right to see to his own well-being, as it says in the Gemara (Pesachim, 68b), “in the first place, when a man does something, he is doing it for himself.”77 In the future, the blessed God will make it clear that the action that he did for himself was only in the sense of “if a person does a mitzvah but not for the sake of Heaven, eventually he will do it for the sake of Heaven.” Eventually he will bring the light out of the darkness, as it is said (Yoel, 4:18), “and a fountain shall come forth from the house of God, and shall water the valley of Shittim [which means acacia wood].”78

Yet the caporet, which corresponds to the heart, and the menorah, which corresponds to the eyes, with these a man must be especially vigilant that they are clean and refined, not corrupted in any way from his own desire for the pleasures of this world. This is as it is said in the Jerusalem Talmud (Berachot, 1:5), “the eye and the heart are the two agents of sin. The eye sees and the heart lusts.” But indeed the eye must be stripped of all the lusts of this world, and used as a pure vessel for the soul, like a clear glass through which the soul looks at the world and decides whether it is good and to receive it, or whether it is evil and to reject it. Yet, when within the eye itself there is any desire or lust for the pleasures of this world, then the eye is not a vessel for the soul, but rather a free agent, free to lust after the affairs of this world. Then the soul does not have the opportunity to distinguish the good from the evil. Therefore the blessed God commanded to be completely refined. The eye shall be clean and stripped of vain lusts, and then it will follow that the soul will only desire that which is the will of the blessed God.

chapter.title: PARSHAT KI TISSA
chapter.p: “And from it Aharon and his sons shall wash their hands and feet.” (Shemot, 30:19)

The act of the Cohanim washing from the laver (kiyor) signifies the removal of affliction, for washing teaches of this, as mentioned in the passage of the beheaded heifer (Devarim, 21:6, the eiglah arufah, performed after finding an unexplained death between cities), “and the elders of the city shall wash their hands over the heifer that is beheaded.” With this they are saying that they have no affliction (associated from the incident), and are clean regarding it. So too, the Cohen who serves needs to wash, meaning that he removes any affliction, nullifying his own mind and will before the will of the blessed God. This means that all his service is only what the blessed God desires.

So it is with how we are commanded to wash in the morning and before a meal, for before one begins to fulfill the needs of the body he must pray to the blessed God. As his dealings in the world may result in his doing something contrary to the will of the blessed God, here he asks the blessed God to remove any desire he has from this action, even from something permitted to us that contains both good and its opposite. For if one were to eat in a way permitted to him and then go on and use the energy from this to transgress the Torah, then it is made clear that he received no good energy from this action. Concerning this we have ritual washing, which is a kind of prayer to the blessed God that from everything we will receive only the good that exists in it.
