“And you shall take fine flour, and you shall bake twelve loaves of bread [challot], two tenths of an ephah in each one.” (Vayikra, 24:5)

Israel is called the challah (bread) of the Holy One, blessed be He, for they sustain the glory of the blessed God in this world the way bread sustains the strength of man. For this, the blessed God sustains them in two worlds, as it says with the creation of man, where it is written (Bereshit, 2:7), “and he formed,” “vaYYatser,” with two yuds, hinting at endurance in two worlds. This is also hinted at in the “two-tenths of an ephah in each one.”
“On the day of Shabbat, on the day of Shabbat [meaning every Shabbat] you shall arrange them before Hashem ….” (Vayikra, 24:8)

Why is the cantillation marking on the first “on the day of Shabbat” kadma ve’azlah, and on the second “on the day of Shabbat” is munach revi’i? The showbreads (Lechem haPanim) teach of the love of the blessed God for Israel. This is as we find in the Gemara (Chagiga, 26b), “see the great love God has in having you before Him [for when the old breads were removed after six days before the new Shabbat, they were as fresh as when they were first placed].” From this great strength53 is realized in Israel, and for this reason the blessed God commanded that two lambs be offered with the bread. Shabbat is the internal quality of the six days of the week. This is explained in the Gemara (Pesachim, 106a), “from the fourth day until Shabbat is called before Shabbat, and from Shabbat until the third day is called after Shabbat [we are always either coming to or coming out of Shabbat].” Therefore the blessed God commanded us to offer two lambs, meaning to give thanks for the past, and to cry out for the future. From the bread, great strengths will come to Israel for the past, for surely the blessed God will complete them for the good. This is why the cantillation marking on the first “on the day of Shabbat” is kadma ve’azlah, meaning for that which had already happened (kadam means “came before”) and been exhausted (azal means “used up or failed”), the blessed God will help, making it for the good. The cantillation marking on the second “on the day of Shabbat” is munach revi’i, meaning that for all of this, man must cry out over what is to come, and place (munach) his mind as far as is humanly possible in order to not deviate from the will of the blessed God. If a man does this, accepting upon himself that for everything in the future he will not deviate from the will of the blessed God as much as is humanly possible for him to do so, then the blessed God will help him with the past. Thus He will show him that he never did anything against the will of the blessed God.

“And the son of an Israelite woman, whose father was an Egyptian, went out among the children of Israel; and this son of the Israelite woman and a man of Israel fought together in the camp. And the Israelite woman’s son blasphemed Hashem’s name ….” (Vayikra, 24:10)

A passage in the holy Zohar reads (Vayikra, 106a), “boring a hole in something that was closed,54 as one would say, ‘and he bore a hole in his door.’” This is because he wanted to open up the depth that is hidden in the future, where the blessed God will refine all of Israel to the point that they will be clean of all sin. Then he would be a complete member of Israel. This is as the Gemara writes (Yevamot, 23a), “an idolater or a slave who has intercourse with a Jewish woman, the child is fit to enter Israel, he is not a bastard, but he is called ‘a tainted Israelite.’” (So he felt incomplete, or “tainted.”) He wanted to open a force where in the future the Holy One, blessed be He, would make such refinements where there would not even remain a residue of the sin among the sinners of Israel. This is as the holy Zohar says (Vayikra, 106a), “He took the final Hei in God’s holy name and cursed him, in order to defend his mother.” This is because the final Hei hints at the world of Asiyah, the realm of making, or physical action. Thus it is, that the blessed God desires that we fulfill His commandments with our actions. However, he wanted to create an opening whereby the blessed God would effect salvation even without the actions of man.

This is as it is said in the Midrash (Tanchuma, Emor, 23; see Rashi on this passage), “This incident was a reaction to the previous section [in Ch. 24, on the challot]. The king usually eats warm bread. Would he eat cold bread?”55 The meaning is, in this world, all the effluence that man receives from the Holy One, blessed be He, is received in time through Shabbat, in place through the Mikdash, and in person through the Patriarchs and the community of Israel. However, he asserted that the blessed God could effect salvation at any time, at any place, and for any individual, all in and of themselves.

Also the Gemara writes (quoted in Rashi on this passage), “He was responding to a previous incident (where the court had judged him guilty). He went to pitch his tent in the encampment of Dan.”56 This is why the section of the one who cursed is included in the Torah, in order to teach us just how much one needs to separate himself from all kinds of angry complaints against God. The one who cursed, since he had distanced himself from the encampment of the Israelites, and had left the court of Moshe guilty, stood and blasphemed. His initial intentions, which were for the sake of Heaven, came out of being an Israelite from the side of his mother. He wanted to plant his roots in the encampment of the Israelites, and his intentions here were good. However, the angry complaints that came later emerged from the side of him that was Egyptian. With a man of Israel, his heart cleaves to the blessed God and his intentions are for the sake of Heaven even if the blessed God denies him some benefit. A true servant of God is one who distances himself according to the will of God, and in doing so he merits the greatest good. We find an example with a descendant of Aharon haCohen who is unfit for service in the Holy Temple because of some physical defect. In distancing himself from the service he thus merits great reward. However, one who is not of the root and branch of Israel, if he is distanced from some benefit, then he cannot contain himself, and will lash out in scorn.

This is as we find in the Gemara (Avodah Zara, 3a), “in the future God will offer the nations the mitzvah of Succa. Then he will take the sun out of its sheath, and make it unbearably hot, so they will not be able to sit in the succa. Upon leaving, they will kick their succot. It is asked, ‘are not Israelites also exempt from the mitzvah of succa if the weather makes it unpleasant?’ Yes, but they would not kick it upon leaving.” With the nations, even if their intention is to fulfill the commandment of the blessed God, if they are prevented from it, they will lash out in scorn (literally, kick).

Therefore the great test of serving God will be with the commandment of succa, for this commandment enjoins us to leave a permanent dwelling and reside in a temporary dwelling. This requires being drawn to any place the will of the blessed God wants us to go, and not to complain even if the blessed God prevents us from performing His commandments. For since this is the will of the blessed God, in not doing the commandment one is now also fulfilling His will. If one who lashes out in scorn when he is prevented from the mitzvah, then this proves that when he was doing the mitzvah, his intentions were not for the sake of Heaven. This is why the blessed God commanded, “go and take out the one who cursed,” for when he wanted to pitch his tent in the camp of the Israelites, his intentions here were also not for the sake of Heaven.

This section is juxtaposed with the section that follows immediately, “He that kills a man shall surely be to death. He that kills an animal,” etc. This is because it is the way of the blessed God, after He had commanded to take out the one who cursed and stone him, which seems like the attribute of severe judgment, and even the shame he had suffered, to command concerning the utmost respect for created beings. With this intention He commanded concerning the restitution for killing an animal. For this reason it is said (Vayikra, 24:19), “and if a man cause a blemish in his neighbor, thus shall it be done to him [paying restitution].” This is to say that there shall be one system of justice. Justice shall be both for the one who has false complaints against God and for all men. “Thus shall it be done back to him” (Vayikra, 24:20) means that all shall see that he that harms another has the very same blemish.57

For this reason the section discussing the succa is juxtaposed with the section discussing the menorah. The blessed God illuminates the eyes of man, and shows him that the blessed God is in charge. So too with the section discussing the showbreads, which hints at the love the blessed God has for Israel, meaning (Chagiga, 26b) “see the great love He has for you! All that the blessed God does is only for the good of Israel.” Yet with one who is not of the root and branch of Israel finds it necessary to bring forth angry complaints against the blessed God, not able to contain himself and spitting it forth from his lips. This is all according to what has been explained in the section on the one who cursed. Such complaints do not come from Israel, for they know that all is for their good.

In this week’s Sedra (Parsha) there are five passages preceding the passage about the festivals. This corresponds to the five kinds of angry complaints that a man can carry in his heart against the stern attributes of the Holy One, blessed be He. The first passage warns the Cohen against contamination from a dead body, and this corresponds to the anger one can have in his heart over the death and absence found in the world.

The second passage discusses the physical defects that would render a Cohen unfit to serve in the temple. A Cohen in this state could harbor anger against the severe judgment of the Holy One, blessed be He, in that He planted him in the branch of Aharon, and would have been fit to offer sacrifices to God and serve Him. Why then did He create him with a defect that prevents him from this Kedusha (holiness), for the Kedusha of a Cohen’s service is immeasurable? Just as we see how much Kedusha there is in the mitzvah of eating matsah, how much more so in the Cohen’s eating the sacrifices, kodshei shamayim, God’s own food, as it were! As we find in the Gemara (Pesachim, 57a), “[how immeasurably awesome it was] when those in the temple would go in and eat of the kodshei shamayim. We see just how precious the eating of sacrifices was in the eyes of God, and all the more so the Kedusha of the Cohen in his service before God. So even seeing a Cohen who is rendered unfit to serve can cause one to be angry at God, for even though he may eat of the sacrifices, he is distanced from the actual service.

The third passage is about the Cohen who becomes impure. Surely the Cohen who was ready to serve God would guard himself beforehand, purifying his heart as much as he could, in order to avoid even an improper thought. How much more so would he then guard himself from defiling his body! Then after, when something happened that distanced himself from the service of the blessed God and the eating of the sacrifices, the great cry would well up inside of him, asking why the blessed God did not help him in order not to be distanced from His service.

The fourth passage discusses blemishes in the sacrifices themselves, where a great cry would come from those bringing the sacrifices, asking why did the blessed God bother to give them goodness and property like that which he had and was unable to offer.

The fifth passage concerns a thanksgiving offering, of which it is said, “he shall eat it on that day.” This means that a man is required to give thanks over the past and cry out for what is to come, so as not to trust in tomorrow, but rather always stand in prayer and the fear of God. Thus he is forbidden from being released from this requirement when the future day comes. This gives way to a cry of anguish in the hearts of mankind, asking why the blessed God cannot simply be a constant refuge of strength, and let them do everything with complete confidence that the blessed God will help them. On this, David haMelech said (Tehillim, 92), “Mizmor Shir, a song of the day of Shabbat,” meaning (Tamid, 33b) “in the future, the day which is eternally Shabbat, on this it is [as the Tehillim continues] ‘good to give thanks to Hashem.’” This means that the Holy One, blessed be He, will teach Binah–Understanding to Israel, causing them to understand that all the events of the past were all for the sake of man’s benefit. This is why Tehillim 92 continues, “and to sing to His supernal name,” for the place from which the blessed God conducts the world above the level of man’s intellect is called “supernal.”

Corresponding to these five passages, Israel was given five passages on the festivals of the year, and in them man receives strength and expansion of his consciousness in order not to come to the angry complaints mentioned above. Corresponding to the first passage we are given the section dealing with Passover, for Passover is the beginning of the illumination that the blessed God gives life to Israel. Shevuot corresponds to the passage dealing with a Cohen who is unfit for service, for with the giving of the Torah all those who were deficient were healed, and Shevuot teaches that the blessed God will heal everything so it will be well. Rosh Hashanah corresponds to the passage about a Cohen who had become impure, for impurity is really sadness, as has been explained (in the second piece in this week’s Parsha). Therefore on Rosh Hashanah there is the mitzvah of sounding the shofar, in order that he will not hear anything that may depress him. Yom Kippur corresponds to blemished sacrifices, for at the moment Israel abandons all forms of pleasure and benefit in this world in order to fulfill the will of the blessed God, then strength and encouragement will come to all their good things and property. Corresponding to a thanksgiving offering, which teaches that a man must always have the fear of God, they were given the mitzvah of succa, meaning that the blessed God will protect man and surround him (just as a succa does even though it is not a permanent structure). The festival of Succot is called “the time of our joy,” meaning that the blessed God will give joy to man in promising never to abandon him.

chapter.title: PARSHAT BEHAR
chapter.p: “And God spoke to Moshe at mount Sinai, saying: Speak to the children of Israel and say unto them, when you enter the land which I give you, you shall let the land rest a Sabbath unto Hashem.” (Vayikra, 25:1–2)

In this the blessed God promises Israel that when they come to the land of Israel their hearts will be at peace. “Land” teaches of the heart. This is “let the land rest,” that their hearts shall be at peace.
“Speak to the children of Israel … you shall let the land rest a Sabbath unto Hashem.” (Vayikra, 25:2)

Three matters are discussed here: Shmitta (seventh “rest” year for the land), freedom of slaves (in the fiftieth year, the Yovel), and Ribit (the prohibition of lending at interest). In all three matters, the Blessed God is warning Israel against putting their trust in anything (of this world) that it would from the human view that it would be possible to rely upon. These three things—Shmitta, Yovel, and Ribit—each take a category of place, time, and person (olam, shana, and nefesh). The acquisition of fields and vineyards is the acquisition one could have in place and placing his trust in it. Concerning this the Blessed One commanded the Shmitta. That is to say, mankind cannot put his trust in places, but rather shall see that they belong to God, for in the seventh (Shmitta) year there is no recognition of ownership in one’s acquisitions (anyone can come in and eat from his field). Through this he shall see that the land is God’s.

Corresponding to placing one’s trust in time, meaning, relying on amassing wealth from selling time, which we call taking interest, the Torah says, “do not take interest from him.” The whole point of interest is one selling his time, as it says in the Gemara (Baba Metsia, 63b), “all compensation of money for waiting [postponing paying a debt] is forbidden.”

As for man’s acquisition in other people, that he feels he may trust his ability to use servants for his needs, God commanded concerning the freeing of slaves in the Yovel year. Thus he sees that he has no ownership of their bodies, and must set them free. Even at the time they are slaves, God commanded “not to force him to serve with hard labor,” that is, to understand that the body of the servant is not his domain.

God commanded these three mitzvot to show man that he may not put his trust in anything connected to time, place, or person—only in the blessed God. This is why these three sections end with the statement, “I am Hashem your God who brought you out of Egypt to give you the land of Canaan.” This means that man should not assume that since these things have been prohibited from us, that His influence toward us is in any way reduced. “I am the Hashem your God who took you out of Mitsrayim.” Mitsrayim (Egypt) comes from the word for narrowness, limitation, to show that the pleasures of the world that are not coming from the side of Holiness are rooted in narrowness and constriction. “To give you the land of Canaan” means that the goodness that God gives us will be in Kedusha (holiness), and we will be able to extend it out to our surroundings, for our inheritance from God is the goodness of Kedusha, “an inheritance without narrowness [limitations].”

p.italic: “… and give the land a Sabbath unto Hashem.”

chapter.p: The point of the sabbatical year, the Shmitta, is to be a sign for Israel, for “the land is God’s and the fullness thereof.” Concerning this the holy Zohar says (Bereshit 3b), “there are [God created] large letters and small letters” (referring to the occasional large or small letter in the Torah scroll). The small letter is Shabbat (ot means both sign and letter). Shabbat is a sign for Israel, for God is the motivator of everything, and the actions of man will do nothing. The large letter-sign is Shmitta, for with the passing of seven years there must necessarily be an entire year in which it is clear that the land is God’s, and that no man has the power of action, only God alone.

“and you shall count seven Sabbaths of years … then proclaim with the call of the shofar… and each man shall return to his portion … in the Yovel year each man shall return to his possession.” (Vayikra, 25:8–10)

The matter of the Shmitta and Yovel corresponds to the way of acting mentioned in the Pirkei Avot (Ch. 5:10), “[one who says] what is mine is yours, what is yours is yours [is a hasid].” Shmitta, the seventh rest year for the land,58 corresponds to the attribute of “what is mine is yours.” In one sense, “the land was given to mankind” (Tehillim, 115:16). One can acquire the land, bringing forth from it all the good things of the world (for all kinds of good things of the world are included in the land, as it is written (Kohollet 3:20), “all was from the dust”). But still, in the seventh year he returns the land to God. At this time he ceases from toil and working the land voluntarily according to the will of God, keeping His ordinances. This is called “what is mine is yours.”

The Yovel, the fiftieth “jubilee” year,59 corresponds to the attribute of “what is yours is yours,” for the commandment of Yovel requires that each one shall return to his possessions and to his family. For in truth, God was fair in how He put man in the land, and divided out an inheritance to each one according to his level, based on the root of his particular soul. He upheld each one on his particular banner, saying to them, “they are My servants” (see Vayikra, 25:42). Yet the progression of events caused mankind to demand many accounts from each other. This one merited to ascend and extend into another’s borders, or to purchase the other to serve him, and the other descended and had to sell his possessions until he eventually had to sell himself into servitude.

Yet since the word of God endures forever and will not change, God forbid, based on the actions of mankind, so God’s temporary judgments that pass over man will not reach the depth of the root of his soul. This is because God created a time for everything to return to its initial portion. Thus He created the Yovel year so that each could return to his place and the portion allotted to him from God, as it is said, “the Yovel year shall be holy to you” (Vayikra, 25:12).

In other words, in the year of Yovel the light of the Kedusha of God will be revealed to all, by means of the proclamation of the shofar on Yom Kippur. Each one will then recognize that the portion of his fathers that was given to him by God and will remain with him. As for that which came to him by means of the actions of man, although there was an agreement of acquisition placing him under another’s domain until now, yet since he does not belong to the other at the root, he must be returned to the place he was originally given. This is the illumination of God in the year of the Yovel, that everyone can return to his place, that everything has its own place. This recognition and understanding can come only after fulfilling the mitzvah of Shmitta, that is, delivering all over to God, and by means this reaching the attribute of “what is yours is yours.”

That is to say, recognizing the place ascribed to everything at its root, as in the saying of the Midrash (Bereshit Rabba, 43:19), “all is in the possession of the blind until God comes and opens their eyes.” This means that even though the human eye will see that this servant belongs to this master, and this field to that one who bought it, yet whoever God illuminates, opening his eyes, will see that all the actions of man will not create a change in the depth of the will of God even minutely. In the Yovel this light will be revealed. This is the attribute of “what is yours is yours,” and is greater than the attribute of “what is mine is yours.”

By means of Shmitta and Yovel one shall see that all the good and wealth he has amassed not by the will of God, but by means of his own efforts, is not his, even though it is in his possession. Therefore this Parsha warns against theft, deception, and interest, to show that in the future it will be apparent that anything that came by means of these methods is not his. This is to counter the one who says to himself, “if it is true that eventually a person will have only what was originally given him by God, then all efforts to gain wealth, to acquire things or expand borders, are in vain. Only what God gave him will remain his.” Concerning this Shlomo haMelech said (Kohollet, 10:1), “a little folly is more precious than honor or wisdom.”

Meaning, although a man may refrain from toil in this world if he understands that none of that which he has gained by his efforts will remain with him, it is the “little folly” within him that caused him to gather wealth even though he knows it is only temporary. Just the same, he may merit by means of his efforts. And even though the time will come for him to return to his portion and everything to return to its place, he will nonetheless profit, for he will return to the other only the measure of what is allotted him. Yet the limit and the border that God set to recognize between one man’s portion and another’s will be added to his border since at the beginning he extended his border into the other’s. In the very action of exerting himself in this world, a little security will remain for him, even from the other’s portion that will be returned. Thus from all the efforts that one exerts in this world, this understanding will remain with him forever.
“And you shall not wrong one another, and you shall fear your God ….” (Vayikra, 25:17)

This verse is also directed to great souls of precious value, when they see someone doing something against the will of the blessed God, and want to accuse against him, punishing him. On this the Holy One, blessed be He, “do not wrong,” and similarly did David haMelech say (Tehillim, 50:20–21, following R. Hirsch’s translation), “You sit and speak against your brother, you slander your own mother’s son. You have done these things, and I stood by in silence, so you thought I was the same as you. Therefore I will reprove you, and set them in order before your eyes.” “You sit and speak against your brother, you slander your own mother’s son” means that he does so even though he is obliged to love his neighbor, as is commanded of him (Vayikra, 19:18), “you shall love your neighbor as yourself.” Man must ask in his prayers for compassion toward his fellow man, but still, he wants to bring accusations against him. Therefore the Blessed God says, “you have done these things, and I stood by in silence.” If the blessed God sees fit to clarify matters, then even the actions of the Tsaddikim will not be meritorious in His eyes, for in the presence of the blessed God who can justify himself, and who can say, “I have refined my heart”? And still, the blessed God is silent, not revealing the shame of any man even if he shall sin.

“You thought that I was the same as you,” for he who brings accusations against his fellow man considers himself and his actions as refined as the will of the blessed God. He believes wholeheartedly that it is the will of the blessed God that he accuse the man who sins. To this grave error the blessed God says, “Therefore I will reprove you, and set them in order before your eyes.” This means that the blessed God will show truth to the face of he who points to the guilt of his neighbor and says that it is God’s will that he do so. God reproves him by showing that the will of the blessed God is only to conceal all the sins of Israel. Thus is it written (Micha, 7:19), “and cast all their sins to the depths of the sea.”

Thus He will conceal them greatly so they will not be revealed and never more seen. So how could one say that the blessed God wants us to expose the guilt of our neighbors, expanding upon their sins? Even though the blessed God commanded man to reprove his neighbor and to try to distance him from all evil as much as is possible, this is only possible in a place where he knows he can help him by bringing him to the good, or through prayer, which will arouse compassion upon him to return him to the path of ethical behavior. However, if he cannot remove him from his errors, then he must judge him meritoriously, and not accuse him. Thus one cannot judge his neighbor as guilty, for perhaps his neighbor’s yetser hara (inclination to evil) is greater than his own. Or, perhaps what he sees as an error or sin is actually permitted to his neighbor, for there are many things that are forbidden to one but permitted to another.

“A man who sells his house in a walled city, he may redeem it a year after it his sold, for a full year he shall have the right of redemption. And if it not be redeemed within the space of a full year, then the house that is in the walled city shall be established forever to him that bought it throughout the generations, it shall not go out in the jubilee.” (Vayikra, 25:29–30)

The passage dealing with houses in walled cities teaches that man knows that all the matters of the Yovel60 are in order to make it clear that there is a time for everything. Even if a man sinned against the blessed God, He will not be angry with him forever. This passage teaches that such a situation only arises when a man sins in affairs between him and the Omnipresent. Although this arouses the attribute of stern judgment where he must sell from his portion or be sold as a servant, it shall not be so forever, for he will go out in the Yovel, and a man shall return to his portion. However, a man may arouse the attribute of stern judgment from a sin between man and his fellow man, with the main example of this being if a man sins by shaming his fellow man publicly with his words. This is what the verse meant when it said, “if a man shall sell his house in a walled city,” for the tongue is called “a house in a walled city,” as it says (Arachin, 15b), “I have given you two walls [the lips].” By means of this a man could, God forbid, sell and lose all his merits, and his fellow man could buy them. On this Shlomo haMelech said (Mishlei, 25:28), “He who cannot control his own spirit is like a city with its walls broken down.”61 The advice given for this is to reconcile with his fellow man within a year, and on this it says, “for a full year he shall have the right of redemption.” “And if it not be redeemed within the space of a full year, then the house that is in the walled city shall be established forever to him that bought it throughout the generations,” meaning that if he does not reconcile with his fellow man, then his merits will permanently remain with his fellow.

This is the explanation of the difference between how the verse is spelled in the Torah scroll and how it is read. “The house that is in the walled city” or “the house that has a wall” is written in Hebrew asher lo homa. Lo is written in Hebrew lamed aleph, which would mean “does not have a wall.” However, we read it as if it were written as lamed vav,” “which has a wall.” The meaning is that a man who has no control over his spirit is called one “without a wall,” and the one who controls his spirit is called one “with a wall.” Thus it is that all the merits of one who cannot control his spirit will remain in the possession of the one who could control his spirit and remained silent.
“But with the cities of the Levites, the Levites may redeem the houses of the cities of their possession at any time.” (Vayikra 25:32)
The Levi means one who serves God; for by means of service a man can reclaim all that he had lost, and receives even additional good.
“… you shall not set up any image of stone in your land, to bow down unto it, for I am Hashem your God.” (Vayikra, 26:1)

“Image” means that a man abandons his consciousness and intellect (becoming like inanimate stone), and will deliver over his life for every matter of God. This is as it is written (Sifre Shoftim 6), “even though it was beloved before Me in the days of the patriarchs.” For now a man need give over his life only to avoid three transgressions (incest, idolatry, and spilling of blood), and only in the Beit Hamikdash (Temple) can a man abandon his intellect before the blessed God.

chapter.title: PARSHAT BECHUKOTAI
chapter.p: “If you walk in My statutes ….” (Vayikra 26:3)

It is written in the Midrash (Yalkut Shemoni Mishlei, Ch. 22), (Tehillim, 111:10) “The beginning of wisdom is the fear of God. It is also written (Mishlei 22:4), ‘following humility [on the heel of humility] is the fear of God.’ The same thing that made wisdom a crown for the head, made humility the heel for the sole.” The matter here is, by the way of nature one may contemplate and arrive at the conclusion that there is a Creator and Master of the world, by means of looking into his intentions for all that is created. But this is only at the onset of one’s bringing himself close to the words of Torah, and then this wisdom is called Yirah, the fear of God. This is because once one knows that there is a Creator and Master, he has to listen to His voice and experience Yirah before Him. Yet after a man achieves the quality of Anavah, humility, then the previous understanding of Yirah will be understood at the blink of an eye, with no need of contemplating and investigating to achieve it, but it will be simple and clear to him. This is “If you walk in My statutes,”62 meaning that His statutes will be carved into your hearts.
“If you walk in My statutes, and keep My commandments, and do them.” (Vayikra, 26:3)

All the while that the Kedusha of the blessed God is not carved63 and permanently installed in the heart of man, he is called “standing.” In this state he needs to constrict himself in all his affairs, not expanding according to his will, for now refraining from action is preferable. And when a man turns to the words of Torah to the extent that they are carved in his heart and fixed there, then he may experience expansion, and go wherever his desire leads him, for God is with him. This is as it is said in the Midrash (Devarim Rabba, Parsha 2:1), “and since there is a Jewish wayfarer.” And it is written in the Gemara (Shabbat, 31b), “since it is written, ‘At the commandment of the Hashem they encamped, and at the commandment of the Hashem they traveled,’ it was like demolishing in order to rebuild on the same site.”
“If you walk in My statutes, and keep My commandments, and do them.” (Vayikra, 26:3)

It is written in the Midrash (Vayikra Rabba, 35:1), “I considered my way, and I turned my feet back to Your testimonies (Tehillim, 119:59). Each day I would plan on going to a certain place, but my feet brought me to the house of prayer and the house of study.” Would you say that David haMelech would, God forbid, have the intention of doing mundane or insignificant things? And furthermore, if his feet would lead him to the house of study yet his intention was not for the sake of Heaven, then it would be like the principle “I did not struggle but I found.”64 Yet a man must struggle in this world. If he brings himself to be purified, then he will be helped to find all the good, but not without struggle. The matter is explained thus. In the realm of Torah study, you will find words of Torah so incredibly precious that other words of Torah will seem small in comparison. This is as we find in the Gemara (Shabbat, 10a), “Those who occupy themselves with prayer but neglect to study Torah are called abandoning eternal life and occupied with temporary life.”

Thus with all matters in the realm of Torah study there are many levels, one over the other. This is as it is written in the Gemara (Megillah, 15a), “The way of the Holy One, blessed be He, is not like the way of flesh and blood. Man first prepares the pot on the fire, and then pours the water into it. Hashem first pours the water, and then prepares the pot, as it is written (Yirmiya, 10:13), ‘with the sound of His gathering a multitude of water in the heavens.’” It is man’s nature, when he wants to do something, he first imagines it, considering what benefit he will receive from the action, and then does it. This is called “preparing the pot,” meaning that he prepares vessels to receive, then considers how to receive, and then receives, that is, he does the action.

The way of the Holy One, blessed be He, is not thus. Rather, He first places the water, and then prepares the pot. With the Torah and the mitzvot that He commanded us to do, He commanded us to learn and do with all our hearts and souls, but not according to the measurement of the boundary of our intellect, to estimate the total goodness of the action. Rather, His will must be fulfilled without any preparation from the side of man, just to gaze before His presence and be drawn after His will. Then after, the Holy One, blessed be He, will show the man the depth of wisdom and good hidden within the action. This is called “pouring the water.”

That is, man must fulfill the will of the blessed God with simplicity, and then afterward “prepare the pot,” where afterward the blessed God shows him the benefits that will be given him from this action. This is as David haMelech said, “I considered my way. Each day I would plan on going to a certain place.” He feared that he might fulfill the will of the blessed God only according to the understanding of his intellect. The awesome depth of the will of the blessed God is here like a mundane action, because the blessed God wants us to fulfill His will without any preparation from the side of man.

This is as it is said, “I considered my way,” for the way is troublesome, as it is written (Berachot, 11a), “the way is bothersome.” Even if he goes to perform a mitzvah it is still called “his way,” for when one goes even to perform a mitzvah, but does it only according to his intellectual understanding, he is disturbed. This is not the case when he goes in the way of simplicity to fulfill the will of the blessed God, for then he is not at all disturbed, for he trusts that God will help him since he is acting with simplicity. “And I turned my feet back to Your testimonies.” Here David haMelech is saying, “even though I thought that perhaps I was not fulfilling the will of the blessed God in a complete way, the blessed God showed me that I had not turned away from His will even a hair’s breadth. I was in the houses of prayer and the houses of study.” Thus his desire was only in places inhabited by the blessed God.

This is the explanation of “and I turned my feet back to Your testimonies.” A testimony is something clear. In a place where man stands before the blessed God without any turning away from his side, there his mind is clear and without disturbance or weakening, and he is not afraid. This is as it is written in the Midrash (Devarim Rabba, 2:2) on the desire of Moshe Rabeynu to enter into the land of Israel, “of this it is written, ‘his desire melted like a moth.’” Even though it is written in the Gemara (Sotah, 14a), “did he need to eat of the fruits of the land?”65 He wanted to fulfill the commandments that one may only do in the land. Nonetheless, it is written of him, “his desire melted like a moth,” for in relation to the will of the blessed God this was called desire, as the fulfillment of commandments and the will of the blessed God must be without any external coloring.

This is the explanation of “if you will walk in my testimonies.” “If” means uncertainty. Even if a man goes in the way of the Torah, he must still be in a state of uncertainty whether he is fulfilling the will of God in a state of completeness, for the will of God is very deep. This is as we find with David haMelech, who feared that perhaps he was not fulfilling the will of God in completeness. This is why David haMelech said (Tehillim, 18:12), “He spreads out darkness as His secret place, and His immediate surroundings are His covering, darkness of waters, thick clouds of the heavens.” “He makes (yashet) darkness be His veil” means the darkness and the uncertainty that comes to man concerning his actions and his fear that he is not fulfilling the blessed God’s will in completeness. Through this the secret place of the truth of Torah will be revealed unto him. Here, yashet, “He spreads out,” means revelation, as in (Shmuel 1, 2:8), “[for the pillars of the world are God’s] and He has set (yashet) the world [revealed it] upon them.” By means of the darkness the hidden is revealed to him, precisely because it engenders uncertainty in man over the words of Torah. Through this process he will arrive at their truth.

This is as it is written in the Gemara (Baba Metsia, 84a), “Reb Yochanan that Reish Lakish used to offer him twenty-four difficulties in the law, and give them twenty-four possible solutions. By this, his understanding of the law was deepened.” Thus it is, when one experiences uncertainty, perhaps he is distanced from the blessed God, and by this sees that he must bring himself closer. “His immediate surrounding are His covering [literally, succa].” Then the blessed God reveals to him that He surrounds and covers the man, even in places where he cannot reach. In places his hand does not reach66 the blessed God will guard him from deviating from His intentions. “The darkness of waters”—this is a man whose lusts and desires bring him darkness and frighten him, lest he is not fulfilling the will of the blessed God in completeness. Here water symbolizes desire, for the most compelling desire found in the world is when one is thirsty for water.

“Thick clouds of the heavens” means that since his desires are in the darkness, by means of this the blessed God will reveal unto him that he can fulfill commandments that seem to contradict one another. “Thick clouds” are practical commandments, from the term “thick” (tangible). Shechakim—“the heavens” are things that contradict one another, for with two opposing forces, when they meet they will pound (yeshachaku) each other. The blessed God will illuminate his eyes to the truth of these seemingly contradictory commandments, like the eradication of Amalek, which appears to be extreme cruelty. And of the one who incites abandonment of the Torah (mesit), it is written (Devarim, 13:9), “do not be merciful.” We see these, and also how the Holy One, blessed be He, warns of being ever compassionate. Then, just man may uphold the attribute of compassion with ease, so too will he be able to fulfill the opposite with ease, for he will be drawn after the will of the blessed God, and according to the will of God will it be easy for him to do.67 We find an example of this with Avraham Avinu, where even though his main attribute was Chesed (loving-kindness), he still stood firm when tested on all sides, and routed the kings of Sodom in war according to the will of the blessed God.
“And you shall eat old store [the obsolete], and you shall take out the old because of the new.” (Vayikra, 26:10)

“Old” is a place where man has begun to give up concerning an action. “Obsolete” is an action where he has already given up completely. The Holy One, blessed be He, promises the man that he will yet see benefit from these actions, for the blessed God will heal, and give them for the good. This is on condition that man accepts upon himself to sustain all His words in justice, not transgressing the will of the blessed God. “He will take out the old because of the new” is his resolution to fulfill all of His words with justice before the blessed God, and he shall not trust in the Holy One, blessed be He, to be merciful with him. This is as it is said in the Gemara (Chagiga, 16a), “do not let your evil inclination incite you by saying, ‘sin, and the blessed God will forgive you.’”68 You shall rather carefully consider all your actions. This is as has been explained on the verse, “on the day of Shabbat, on the day of Shabbat you shall arrange,” above in Parshat Emor.
“And you shall perish among the nations, and the land of your enemies shall devour you.” (Vayikra, 26:38)

It is written in the Gemara (Makkot, 24),69 “‘Rav said, I have misgivings about that verse, And you shall perish among the nations.’ Rav Papa responded, ‘Could it not perhaps be understood as something lost and searched for, as it is written, I have gone astray like a lost sheep; seek your servant.’” Rav was perplexed at the sin of a nocturnal emission, where it seems as if it is beyond man’s ability to rectify. Therefore he was answered with “perhaps it could be understood as something lost and searched for,” meaning that the blessed God has the power to return all to Kedusha. After this, the Gemara continues, “what really perplexes me is the second half of the verse, ‘and the land of your enemies shall eat you up.’” This refers to the sin of engaging in sexual relations with an Aramite, which seems to be even further from being able to fix. Thus he was answered, “it is like the way squash and pumpkins are eaten.” He said this because it is the nature of squash and pumpkins, that once they are plucked from above (the ground), they immediately return and sprout again. In the same way, the blessed God can fix even this, for he will make it clear that no sin existed in Israel at the root, God forbid.
“Speak to the children of Israel and say to them, a man who makes a vow to give the estimated value of a person to Hashem.” (Vayikra, 27:2)

After the verses of stern rebuke, the blessed God gave Israel a stronghold in the section dealing with values, namely, that a man can redeem himself from anything. Four kinds of redemption are mentioned: houses, fields, people, and animals. This corresponds to the four times the word “seven” is written in the verses of rebuke.70 “Seven” represents how the blessed God is exacting down to a hair’s breadth. For this, He gave us four ways to redeem ourselves. This is not that the man himself may effect the redemption, but rather that if one sees that another needs redemption, he can redeem him. This is as it is said in the Gemara (Arachin, 20a), “one who says, ‘so and so’s value is upon me.’” In the section dealing with values for redemption (Ch. 27), we find thirty-three verses, not counting the verse “and God spoke,” and the final verse “these are the commandments,” which do not deal with the subject of values. These correspond exactly to the thirty-three verses of rebuke. Corresponding to the verse (Vayikra, 26:38), “and you shall be destroyed among the nations, and the land of your enemies shall devour you,” which is the greatest of all fears, is the verse (Vayikra, 27:25), “and every estimation shall be according the holy shekel.” In this way, every verse in the section of values for redemption corresponds to a verse in the Parsha of stern rebuke in order to bring redemption to all that is said there.
chapter.ftnote: 1. For a complete explanation of this, see the first selection in Parshat Shlach L’cha.
2. It must be remembered that the word for sacrifice, karban, has the same root in Hebrew as karov—“close.” One comes close to God through the sacrifices.
3. Those who bring the sacrifices do not eat them afterward; this was the privilege of the Cohanim.
4. See Daniel, 7:10, “a fiery stream [nahar di nur] issued and came forth …”
5. See Parshat Chukat, in the selection “and Israel camped at Ovot,” for more from the author on the “removal of affliction.”
6. This phrase is taken from a highly relevant passage in the Gemara (Baba Batra, 75a), which reads:

Rabbah in the name of Rav Yochanan said further: The Holy One, blessed be He, will make seven canopies for every Tsaddik; for it is said, “And the Hashem will create over the whole dwelling of Mount Tsion, and over her assemblies, a cloud of smoke by day, and the shining of a flaming fire by night; for over all the glory shall be a canopy” (Yeshayahu, 4:5). This teaches that the Holy One, blessed be He, will make for everyone a canopy corresponding to his status. Why is smoke required in a canopy? Rav Chanina said: Because whoever is envious of the scholars in this world will have his eyes filled with smoke in the world to come. Why is fire required in a canopy? Rav Chanina said: This teaches that each one will be burned because of his jealousy at the superior canopy of his friend. Alas, for such shame! Alas, for such reproach!

7. The sons of Aharon each offered a censer full of incense but lit it from “outside fire,” and as R. Shlomo Carlebach once explained, they were trying to bring the Messiah, by making the outside fire like the inside fire.

8. Perhaps because the smoke from the incense rises up to connect heaven and earth, or because the ten sefirot and the surrounding light out of which all is formed are hinted at in the eleven spices in the incense. Furthermore, as mentioned elsewhere, Rabbi Yitzhak of Acco writes in his explanation Meirat Eineihem, that smoke, ashan, is an acronym for: olam, shana, nefesh, meaning place, time, and soul, the three main components of existence, as discussed in the Sefer Yetsirah.
9. Meaning that anyone who merits to enter into a height of the secrets of the Torah as they did, must be as the Cohen Gadol, the high priest, and be enwrapped in the intense fear of the blessed God.

10. Rav Nehemiah explains it in this way: ‘Wherefore have ye not eaten’ etc? (Vayikra, 10:17). ‘Perhaps,’ said Moshe to Aharon, ‘its blood entered the innermost sanctuary?’ [and therefore should have been burned]. ‘The blood was not brought into the sanctuary’, he answered. ‘Perhaps it was taken outside of the boundary [taken outside of the Temple, and therefore should have been burned]?’ he suggested. ‘It was in the sanctuary’, he replied. ‘And perhaps you offered it in a state of mourning, and thus disqualified it?’ ‘Moshe’, he answered, ‘did my sons offer it? I offered it.’ Then he exclaimed, ‘Behold, the blood of it was not brought within, and it was in the sanctuary, then you should certainly have eaten it, as I commanded, that they should eat it in a state of mourning.’ He said to him: ‘And there have befallen me such things as these, and if I had eaten the sin-offering today, would it have been pleasing in the sight of the Hashem (Vayikra, 10)? Perhaps you heard it in this way only about sacrifices of the hour (special sacrifices)? For if [you would apply it] to the [regular] sacrifices for all generations, [you may argue] a minori from tithe, which is of lesser holiness. For if the Torah said of the tithe, which is of a lesser holiness, “I have not eaten thereof in my mourning,” how much the more does it apply to sacrifices, which are more holy?’ When Moshe heard that, it pleased him. He admitted his mistake and Moshe was not ashamed to say, ‘I had not heard it’, but said, ‘I heard it and forgot.’

11. The first dispute was between the sun and moon, who were originally both great lights, equal in size. The moon asserted “two kings cannot wear the same crown,” so God told the moon, “go and reduce yourself.” This is, as it were, the introduction of dispute in the world.
12. Regel in Hebrew means both “habitual” (hergel) and “foot.”
13. Meaning, if God’s name surrounds it, then it is always good.
14. A zealot may harm one found having intercourse with an Aramite, as Pinchas did.

15. For we are all born of woman, a relatively low level in one respect in relation to the higher powers, “what is man that you shall be mindful of him?” in Tehillim 8:5, but our appreciation of the Creator and His creation makes us beloved in His eyes.

16. The connection between “male” (zachar) and “memory” (zecher) is apparent here, a male child symbolizing the memory of the initial preparation of salvation that comes to fruition after the process in serving God described above.
17. The Isbitser says precisely “stop,” which is ma’atsor in Hebrew, comprised of the same letters as metsora, leprosy.
18. He took his very handicap of spreading gossip, and used its power to spread Torah.
19. Different forms of leprosy would create diferent levels of impurity. Here a scab would have been a secondary or derivative level of impurity.

20. This matter is explained in the Mei HaShiloach on the book of Melachim 1, Ch. 22 concerning Rechavoam. There it says, “Then King Rechavoam sent Adoram, who was over the forced labor; and all Israel stoned him with stones, and he died. Therefore King Rechavoam exerted to mount his chariot, to flee to Jerusalem. The matter is discussed in the Gemara (Sanhedrin, 48b), ‘Rechavoam had an issue [signaled in that he had to exert himself to mount his chariot]. This shows that his sin, for “issue” means rushing and preceding the proper time, even though afterward the kingdom would be his. And thus, in the future the kingdom of the house of David will spread over all of Israel, yet here, with Rechavoam, he preceded his time, in exerting to mount his chariot.”
21. A time when we as a nation undergo spiritual purification in order to be united as a bride with her groom, with the blessed God on Shevuot.
22. Which could also be understood as “all of the tribes were twelve,” meaning he included all of them in the blessing.

23. As in the verse in question, where anyone of Israel who is afflicted and comes to the Cohen uses the word huvah (brought) a term that is only found elsewhere in the Torah with regard to the service of the Cohen.
24. An angel, which upon seeing would inspire the fear of God, is called by the same Hebrew word as “city,” eer.
25. Shmira or self-guarding.
26. And the word tsitsit is itself connected to the word for looking, tsits.
27. That is to say, the first thing he is asking for with every matter is that it be will of God, to such an extent that even his personal desires are the will of God.
28. “Affliction” means a personal motive that would sway him from clearly seeing God’s will. See above, Parshat Chukat, under “and the children of Israel camped at Ovot,” for more on this.
29. In other words, it took him ten days to make sure that this was what God wanted and not just what he wanted.
30. Here Pinchas is the Cohen.

31. It is written in the Tikkunei Zohar, Tikkun 70, “ ‘Come and See! There are those who speak with eye movements, others with hand gestures, others with head movements, others with body movements, and others with leg movements. This is, everywhere his soul is, there that place moves more.’ Rabbi Elazar said, ‘father, is it not known that the soul [neshama] resides in the heart [mind], and spreads forth to all the extremities of the heart? He said to him, ‘My son, of this it is written (Ruth, 3:7), ‘she uncovered her feet, and laid down.’ According to the actions of man, thus the soul goes out of her place, and descends below her place. This is like the Shechina, of whom it is written (Yeshayahu, 50:1), “for your transgressions your mother was sent away.” Complete tshuva returns her to her initial place. At the time that the neshama is in the heart she is called the queen. With one’s sins, it descends, until it reaches the feet. This is why certain parts of the body move more than others.’ ”
32. The section of the Gemara, Sanhedrin 99a, that interprets the verse in Yeshayahu deals with the question of when the Messiah will come; see there for a clearer understanding.

33. This is hinted at in the name of the vowel, kamats, which is related to the word for restricting, delineating, like the komets offering, a hand measurement of grain. Also, in the kabbalistic understanding of the vowel, kamats represents the Crown, Keter, which is wholly connected to what is above, Malchut, of the upper level. In a sense, separated from and encircling the body of its own arrangement of sefirot as a crown is on top of the head.
34. See note 61, Sefer Shemot for more on tekifut.

35. Rabbi Yitschok also said: Why were the reasons for Torah laws kept hidden?—Because in two verses reasons were revealed, and they caused Shlomo haMelech the greatest sage in the world, to stumble. Thus it is written, “He shall not multiply wives for himself.” To which Shlomo haMelech replied, “I will multiply wives yet let my heart not be perverted.” However, we read, “When Shlomo haMelech was old, his wives turned his heart away.” It is further written, “He shall not multiply to horses for himself”; concerning which Shlomo said, “I will multiply them, but will not let Israel return to Egypt.” However we read, “And a chariot came up and went out of Egypt for six hundred shekels of silver.”
36. This also shows how peyot teach of the essential connection between the intellectual and the heart, or kindness.

37. R. Hirsch understands nechila as related to nahala, or inheritance, meaning, crying out for what God gives us based on our actions. The Meiri relates it to the sound of the crying itself, for the word nechila is related to the word for the drone of a swarm of bees.
38. The verse “you shall not offer,” refers to animals fit to offer in the temple. What about an animal where even its price cannot be used to buy a temple sacrifice?
39. Or damaged, for prior to this experience he was considered one of the great homiletic interpreters of the Torah in his generation.
40. The Gemara goes on to discuss whether or not she could have been impregnated by semen in a bathtub.

41. In truth there is only the difference of a hair’s breadth that the firmament separates between them, only one must accept them according to the will of the blessed God. Similarly it is with the lamb offered with the omerbarley offering, which is placed double—two esronim of barley representing the lower waters and the upper waters, and the lamb hints at the firmament separating between them. Tashlum.

42. “On the outside” means that they deemed him mentally unfit, or that he did not have a clear understanding of the mysteries of creation. The Steinsaltz Gemara quotes the explanation of the “Otsar Hakavod,” which interprets the upper and lower waters as purely spiritual matters, and the discussion is trying to find the source of supernal entities and of the lower entities. According to R. Yehoshua, on the first day of creation there is no separation between any of these entities at all, and everything existed as a single unified creation. Ben Zoma understood the description in the Book of Bereshit describes the order in which everything was created, and R. Yehoshua understood that there were elements mentioned in the creations of the first day that only came into being later.

43. Ben Zoma made the mistake in understanding there to be a great difference between the upper waters and the lower waters, for truly they have one source, as water signifies desire. Man possesses two kinds of desire, one that was imprinted in him from his birth, as explained in the Midrash (Rabba Bereshit, 8), that the world is filled with loving-kindnesses (chasadim), and in this one could make the mistake of being merciful with the cruel. However, when a man is merciful and experiences desire from the side of his intellect, it is without any impurity. If a man were to direct the loving-kindness in his nature to the will of the blessed God, then it is even far greater than that which he does with his intellect.

Therefore it does not say in the Tehillim (148) that the waters that are below the heavens shall praise the name of God, for what is man, and what can he do with his intellect? But that which he can do with his nature, this is the Godly power within him. Thus it is that Ben Zoma understood a great difference, where truly, in the future, when God will make it clear that everything in the world came from Him, then it will be clearly seen that nothing separates between the upper waters and the lower waters. This is why, before entering into the garden of the secrets of the Torah, Rabbi Akiva warned (Chagiga, 14b), “when you arrive at the stones of pure marble, do not say, ‘water, water,’” for the main point of his warning was not to identify water two times, because at their source, they are one. Understand this. Giliyon Mei HaShiloach by Gershon Chenoch Lainer, the Rebbe of Radzin ZY”A.
44. The more interpretive of the ancient Aramaic translations of the Torah.
45. Or strikes that day itself, imbuing it with cruelty (Sulam).
46. The Gemara says that Rava had only said this to sharpen (test) Abaye.
47. Shevuot is fifty days after Passover, and until then each day is ritually counted with a blessing (sefirat ha’omer), each day representing one of the fifty gates.
48. They are: above, below, east, west, north, and south, which are the six walls of the succa. Tashlum.
49. The four species waved on Succot are divided into that which has both taste and smell, that which has taste but no smell, smell with no taste, and neither taste nor smell.

50. R. Even Yisrael (Steinsaltz) comments that this is because palm branches are something that last a long time and are always useful. Rashi says that there was an industry surrounding them in the ancient world.
51. See Devarim 8:8, where honey means dates.

52. See Shmuel 2, 23:16. “And the three mighty men broke through the army of the Philistines, and drew water from the well of Beth-Lehem, that was by the gate, and took it, and brought it to David. Nevertheless he would not drink of it, but poured it out to Hashem. And he said, Be it far from me, Hashem, that I should do this; is not this the blood of the men who went risking their lives? Therefore he would not drink it. These things did these three mighty men do.”
53. Tekifut or azut d’Kedusha, meaning holy brazenness; see note 61, Sefer Shemot.
54. This is because yikov means both to pierce and to blaspheme.
55. Meaning that he was denying the miracle that the twelve challot in the tabernacle stayed warm and fresh all week. Eyts Yosef.

56. He asserted that he was of the tribe of Dan, but this was so only from his mother’s side. They told him that they only camp “according to their father’s house.” So in anger he went out and blasphemed.
57. In his soul.

58. Shmitta is the sabbath of the land, once every seven years, where agricultural work in the land of Israel is suspended, and the land lies fallow. Also the produce within fields and orchards become open for the public to come and take.
59. In the Yovel (Jubilee) year, once every fifty years, slaves are freed, and acquired property returns to its original owners.
60. See previous note.

61. It needs to be noted that the word ruach, “spirit,” can also mean breath, and hence one who refrains from using his breath and voice to shame another. Keep this in mind whenever the phrase “controls his spirit” is used.
62. “Statute,” Chok in Hebrew, is closely related to the word for carve, Chokek.
63. See previous note.
64. See the last selection in Parshat Vayeitse on “I did not struggle but I found.”

65. The text of the Gemara (Succa, 14a) reads: “Why did Moshe Rabeynu desire to enter the land of Israel? Did he want to eat of its fruits or satisfy himself from its produce? But Moshe said, ‘Many precepts were commanded to Israel which can only be fulfilled in the land of Israel. I wish to enter the land so that they may all be fulfilled by me.’ The Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, ‘are you looking only to receive the reward? I will count it as if you performed them.’”
66. Places he does not understand.

67. According to the understanding of man, he cannot hold two opposites on one subject. This is because man wants to be at peace, and therefore he cannot simultaneously fight two opposites. But indeed, one who is drawn after the will of God is not partial to any one side, and the blessed God will illuminate him to this. Therefore the Patriarchs are called a merkava (chariot) for the Shechina, because they are drawn after the will of the blessed God. Tashlum Mei HaShiloach.

68. The Gemara (Chagiga, 16a) reads: “Rabbi Yehuda son of Rabbi Nahmani, the translator of Reish Lakish, expounded: What is the meaning of the verse, Do not trust in a friend, do not put your confidence in a familiar friend? If the evil inclination say to you: Sin and the Holy One, blessed be He, will forgive you, do not believe it, for it is said: ‘Do not trust in a friend,’ and ‘friend’ means none other than one’s evil inclination, for it is said: ‘For the inclination of man’s heart is evil.’ And ‘familiar friend’ is none other than the Holy One, blessed be He, for it is said: You are the familiar friend of my youth.”

69. The text of the Gemara (Makkot, 24a) reads: Rav said, “I have misgivings about that verse, ‘And you shall perish among the nations’” (Vayikra, 36:38). Rav Papa attacked this, saying, “Could it not perhaps rather be taken in the sense of something lost and searched for (as avad in Hebrew could mean both perished or lost), as it is written, ‘I have gone astray like a lost sheep, seek Your servant’” (Tehillim, 119:176). But it was the latter part of the verse that perplexed Rav, “And the land of your enemies shall eat you up.” Mar Zutra then pointed out a difficulty, saying, “Might it not be understood in the way that cucumbers and pumpkins are eaten? (For they ripen at different times in different parts of the country. This could be a hint at national schism and disunity.)”
70. As in (Vayikra, 26:28), “and I will chastise you seven times over your sins.”

chapter.title: PARSHAT BAMIDBAR
chapter.p: “And God spoke to Moshe in the wilderness of Sinai in the Tent of Appointed Meeting, on the first day of the second month, in the second year from their departure from the land of Egypt, saying, Raise [count] the heads of all the congregation of the children of Israel.” (Bamidbar, 1:1–2)

“Raise” signifies elevation. By means of counting the number of all the tribes, each individual will experience elevation, and a special significance will be seen in each one. This is as it is written (Hoshea, 2:1), “And the number of the children of Israel will be as the sand of the sea, which cannot be measured or counted.” This verse seems to contradict itself (v. Gemara Yoma, 22b), for at the beginning it says, “and the number,” implying that they can be counted, and at the end it says, “which cannot be measured.” But in truth, the community of Israel as a whole is without number, and what was said, “and the number,” was said concerning the specific souls of Israel, that each one should have a number.

This is said in the sense that something that is counted will be important in the eyes of the blessed God, as it is written (Tehillim, 87:6–5, Tr. of Hirsch), “God will count when he registers the peoples.” “But of Zion it is said, every man that was born there, the Most High maintains her thus.” “God will count when he registers the peoples” meaning that the Providence of the Holy One, blessed be He, also extends to the nations of the world, yet not in an individual way, but over them all, in a general way, for the maintenance of the species. “But of Zion it is said, every man that was born there, the Most High maintains her thus” means that the Providence of the Holy One, blessed be He, is over each individual soul.

This is the meaning of “and the number of the children of Israel,” that every one will be absolutely necessary. The greatness of the blessed God is seen in the entire community of Israel as a whole, and if just one member of that community is missing then the mixture will be deficient. It is as if the image of the king were made up of a mosaic of many small parts, and if just one of the parts were missing, then the picture of the king would be lacking. So at the time when each member of Israel is counted, then He is the greatness in all of Israel, for each one of Israel is a portion of the blessed God. This is as it is written (Devarim, 32:9), “for His nation is a portion of God.” Each individual possesses one of the attributes of the Holy One, blessed be He, and at the time when that individual is counted, then the blessed God himself is present in that attribute which he possesses, and clearly whatever is being counted is at that time the greatest of all. This is how each member of Israel has a special state of elevation.
“… in the wilderness of Sinai, in the Tent of Appointed Meeting ….” (Bamidbar, 1:1)

It is written in the Holy Zohar (Bamidbar, 117a), “since the Torah and the Mishkan [Tabernacle] were established, the Holy One, blessed be He, wanted to count its soldiers, how many soldiers there were for the Torah and how many soldiers there were for the Mishkan.” This can be understood through what is written in the Tikkunei Zohar (70a), (the word) “In the Beginning (Bereshit, in Hebrew, which can be divided into, Bet Reshit) means two beginnings. These ‘two beginnings’ are the two commandments, ‘and you shall contemplate [the mitzvot] day and night,’ and the commandment of the king to write a second Torah scroll [in addition to the one that every Jew is commanded to write].” Even when it comes to a man’s thoughts to do something good, the man still must make sure that his heart is refined and cleaned from all dross and refuse. If he does not, then this action will also not be complete but lacking. We find this even with the Patriarchs, all of whose actions were done for the sake of Heaven. However, at the times when they did not intend to the deepest levels of the will of the blessed God, then this manifested itself in later generations in souls that were not good. For when it comes to thought, then there is no tsaddik in the land who can say, “I have refined my heart and purified my mind,” as is explained in the verse (Shemot, 13:18), “and the children of Israel left Egypt armed.”

This is as King David said (Tehillim, 93:2), “Your throne is henceforth [meaz] established, You who are everlasting,” which the Holy Zohar explains (Shemot 54a) on the word [meaz] “henceforth,” which is made up of an aleph and a zayin, “aleph rides on zayin.” Aleph teaches of the beginning of a thought, and zayin (also meaning seven) teaches of the completed action, for zayin corresponds to the seven days of creation. So when the thought is connected to the action it is then called az (aleph and zayin together). This is the explanation of the two commandments mentioned above. “And you shall contemplate the Torah night and day” corresponds to thought and will, which are in complete accordance with the will of the blessed God, and the commandment for the king to write an additional Torah scroll corresponds to action. This is why it is called “a commandment for the king,” because the actions of King David were greatly refined in the will of the blessed God. This is the explanation of “soldiers of the Torah and Soldiers of the Mishkan.” “Soldiers of the Torah” is the power of thought and the desires of Israel for the words of Torah. “Soldiers of the Mishkan” means the words of Torah that are instilled as a dwelling in the heart of Israel to the extent that even the actions that come to being are an expression of the will of the blessed God.
“Count the heads … number them according to their armies, you and Aharon. And a man of each tribe shall be with you ….” (Bamidbar, 1:2–4)

The matter of counting relates to what is said in the Gemara (Berachot, 58a), “one man’s mind is not similar to another’s.” The blessed God allotted to each one goodness and life, and one is not similar to his fellow. Therefore it is said, “count [literally, “raise”] the head,” or to stand each one in his proper place. By means of this he will be in his place, prominent and elevated. Therefore it is said, “you and Aharon,” because Aharon corresponds to the “soldiers of the Mishkan [Tabernacle],” which signifies Divine service, and Moshe signifies the “soldiers of the Torah.” All of the life of Israel is included in these two, Torah and service. “And a man of each tribe shall be with you,” for the prince of the tribe knows the proper place of each one in his tribe. If he were to exchange one man’s place for another’s, then the condition of the tribe would not be complete. This may be likened to one who plants a garden in an intricate order, where if one planting is missing or exchanged for another, then it will be recognized that the garden is not complete. And Israel is called (Yesahaya, 61:3), the planting of God in which He is glorified.”
“And with you shall be a man of each tribe, he is the head of his father’s house.” (Bamidbar, 1:4)

This shows that each tribe needed three: Moshe, Aharon, and the prince of the tribe. This was according to the law and judgment whereby a portion of the Kedusha of the Patriarchs exists within each tribe. According to the way in which these three saw to how many souls this Kedusha could be divided and spread forth, thus was the number of souls in the tribe. This is as we find in the Gemara (Baba Batra, 121b), “Yair son of Menashe was equal to greater part of the Sanhedrin,” and they needed these three: Moshe, Aharon, and the prince of the tribe. This goes according to what is written in the holy Zohar (Shemot, 200a), “there are three points to the Torah.”1 Thus we find that when one wants to enjoy anything in this world, he should see that it meets three qualifications. First, it should be sweet to the palate. Second, it should not damage his health. This is as it is written in the Gemara (Pesachim, 42b), “Everything that is good for this one is bad for the other one.” And third, he should not be too immersed in this delight, for he must make sure that he is well for the rest of his life, and if the delight disturbs him too much, he will not take care to prepare tomorrow’s needs.

Thus it is with matters of Torah. First, a man must look toward the world to come, but not disturb himself from his affairs in this world. Second, he may not harm any one of Israel, for all of Israel makes up one body, and if he harms another it is as if he is harming one of his own limbs. Third, the man must take care that it is also good for him. Thus Moshe Rabeynu is called (Zohar, Vayikra, 53b), “the agent of the King,” as he was appointed by the blessed God to see that when the assembly of Israel expands, it does not, God forbid, expand against God’s will. Aharon is called “the agent of the Queen,” and it was his job to see that each tribe expands, it does not expand in a way that will distress other tribes. Each prince would stand by its tribe when it was drawing a flow of goodness and wanted to increase. Just as these three judged the situation, thus would be the number of souls in the tribe.

Of the tribe of Gad it is said, “the family of Izni.” In Parshat Pinchas, Rashi explains, “Izni is the Etsbon family, and I do not know why the name was changed.” This can be understood according to the passage in the Gemara (Ketubot, 5b), “Why are the fingers [Etsbaot, like the name of the Etsbon family] of man in the shape of a spike? This way, if he hears something that is not proper, he can put his finger in his ear.” Therefore when they descended into the impure air of Egypt, they went by the name Etsbon (like finger), for they would close their ears in order not to receive anything that was not the will of God. Then when they entered the land of Israel, where the air is filled with Kedusha, they were called “Izni [whch means ear],” for their ears were open to hear and receive the Kedusha of God from the goodness of the land.

“And God spoke to Moshe and Aharon saying, each man shall camp according to his banner, with the sign of his father’s house, the children of Israel shall camp encompassing the tent of appointed meeting.” (Vayikra, 2:1)

It is written in the Midrash (Tanchuma, Bamidbar, 11), “What will we see in the Shulamite, as the dance of Machanayim.” The Midrash explains that this verse refers to the camping of the tribes. (The nations say “return—we will make you leaders and noblemen. “As the dance,” Israel responds, “you could not come close to giving us the greatness that Hashem gave us in telling us how to camp in the desert.”) When we camped according to the banners, each one was standing on his rightful place at his root, and he knew his place. In the same way the names of the princes of each tribe teaches of the preciousness included in every member of that tribe.

“[The prince] of Yehuda was Nachson ben Aminadav.” Nachson teaches of anger as it is related to the word for snake, “nachash.” It appeared as if there was anger in the tribe of Yehuda. Therefore the blessed God testified that the anger in Yehuda was filled with the spirit of self-sacrifice and giving. (The last three letters in Aminadav, are the root of the word for volunteering, nedivut.) Ben—son of—means deep understanding (havana), so he was called Ben Ami Nadav, which means that at the depths he was filled with the ability to give. This is as it is explained in the holy Zohar (Vayikra, 40b), “[The king establishes the land by justice,] but he who demands gifts overthrows it (Mishlei, 29:4). ‘He who demands gifts’ is Eisav. But did not David also demand gifts? With David it is different, for of him it is written, with beautiful eyes.’ [Shmuel 1, 16:12].” Because the Torah describes David’s red hair, it seems on the outside to be a sign of anger. This is as we find in the Midrash (Bereshit Rabba, 63:11), “when Shmuel saw the redness of David, he feared that he was one who would spill blood like Eisav, so the Holy One, blessed be He, said to him, see his beautiful eyes. This one [Eisav] takes it upon himself to kill. But David does not take it upon himself to kill, rather goes according to the judgment of the Sanhedrin.”2

“Of Yissachar was Netanel ben Tsooar.” “Netanel” which literally means “given from God,” means that the blessed God gives Chochma (wisdom) in his heart. “Tsooar” is related to the word “young.” He saw himself as small and young, and as such knew that he had no power from his own side. Thus he was a vessel ready to receive all the effluence of the blessed God. “Tsooar,” in the sense of young, also shows that he knew his place, and knew who he was smaller than in comparison. The blessed God effused understanding unto him, as he was the first one to give the advice to offer sacrifices for the dedication of the Tabernacle, as is found in the Midrash (Bamidbar Rabba, 12:19). This advice (the understanding, and the first sacrifice) was effused to him from the blessed God, so therefore his very name means “given from God,” as God gave him Chochma. Notwithstanding his divinely bestowed wisdom and understanding, he still knew his place, knowing who he was younger and smaller than, and knew that Yehuda ruled his brothers, so therefore Yehuda offered the first sacrifice.

“And for Zevulun, Eliav ben Cheilon.” There is great strength in this tribe. The name “Eliav ben Cheilon” teaches of this, for all their strength was only from the forms of Chochma that the blessed God effused to them. Thus even when they were occupied with worldly matters, even then the blessed God effused strength and vigor to them in order to succeed. This is Eliav ben Cheilon, for Av, meaning “father,” represents wisdom,3 and, Cheilan represents strength, as mentioned above.

“For Reuven, Elitsoor ben Shdeioor.” Elitsoor means strength, from the word for rock, Tsoor.4 Shdeioor teaches that all his strength comes from the great light that God illuminates (Shadday is God the Almighty, and oor is light). This is precisely true for the tribe of Reuven, as Reuven signifies sight (Reu means see, hence light). Thus he sees in every situation how he is standing in the presence of God. This brings him to a great state of simcha (joy), as it is written (Mishlei, 15:30), “Joy comes to the heart from the light of the eyes.”

“For Shimon, Shlumiel ben TsooriShaddai.” Shloomiel means that his heart is faithful to the blessed God (Shloom—Shalem, or faithfulness. E-l—God). Ben TsooriShaddai and because his heart is faithful the blessed God will save him. (Again, Tsoori, “my Rock” and Shaddai as the Almighty God who brings salvation.)

“For Gad, Elyasaf ben Deu’el.” In other words, even though the blessed God gives him the power to gather (assaf) all the good in the world, still, he recognizes that the Creator is in control (Deu’el means “know that there is God”), and will not cease from upholding the Torah even when wealthy. At times when he is in tune with the attribute of the love of God he is called Reu’el, from the word for beloved friend, Reiah. Then at the time when he is in tune with the attribute of the fear of God, he is called Deu’el, know that there is God. Owing to this, in the section of the offerings of the princes, he gave the sin offerings, meaning that each one understood where he was lacking and there precisely was the principal state of completeness, for real completeness is when one recognizes his deficiency. This is as it is written (Kohellet, 10:1), “more precious than wisdom or honor is a little foolishness.” This is why he is called Deu’el when he is offering the sacrifices, for when a man comes to the state of completeness he needs fear.

“For the tribe of Yosef, Efriam Elishama ben Amihud.” This concerns the place when one is overpowered by the lust for any good, for the name, Elishama is related to (Mishlei, 15:30), “a good report [Shmua] fattens the bones,” and this is the place where lust overpowers the man.
